Title: What made the building of the Panama canal an almost impossible feat?
Question: A. How were the obstacles elliminated?


B. Why was the completion of this massive project which took ten years to build such a big deal when it finally opened?
Answer: A. Various diseases hampered the construction project because many people died.  Yellow fever and Malaria were the most deadly of them, because before the cause of them was discovered (mosquitoes) they didn't know how to treat the disease.

Also the original French plan called for a sea level canal like Suez.  Unfortunately for the French the Panamanian landscape didn't allow them to dig so easily as they did in Suez, and the technology they were using in Panama was the same one as they used in Suez, which was all wrong.

When the US got the rights to build the canal arising from the Hay - Buneau Varilla treat of 1903, they reengineered the plans and decided to go for a lock type canal, rather than a sea level canal.  They based this on a prior study from a French engineer.  They also brought new technology with them, for example Concrete.  Remember we're talking about 1903 here.

Also the US got a hold of the research that a Cuban medic called Carlos Finlay did on Yellow Fever where he discovered that mosquitoes were the vectors causing the disease, and the incubation time needed for the mosquitoes to transfer the disease.

With that the US drained swamps, and they fumigated the entire Canal Zone, along with the Panamanian Cities of Cristobal, Colon and Panama to get rid of the mosquitoes.

B. Actually it wasn't a big deal when the Canal opened in 1914.  It was the smallest story on the front page news.  Remember WWI just broke out in Europe, so the news from the battlefront were more interesting than the first transit of the canal.  By the way it was done by the Steamship Ancon.

Now regarding commerce and the military advantage it gave the US, it was a big deal.  Ships could now shorten the time it took them to go around the Cape of Horns in South America, and also for those ships that had to cross the Cape of Good Hope in South Africa.  The US military could complement their fleets just crossing some vessels through the Canal.  Think about all the savings it brought to commerce, and the possibilites to the military strategists at that time.

Also until 1977 the Panama Canal was controlled by the US Military, not the US Federal Government as some still think.  The office handling the Panama Canal affairs was in the Pentagon, not the Secretary of Commerce.  After 1977 with the new Panama Canal Treaties (they were 3 treaties in one single body) The Neutrality Treaty declared the Panama Canal neutral in all times of wars and crisis, therefore now any ship couldn't be denied the right to go through the Panama Canal.  Although I don't believe that prior to 1977 the US actually denied transit except in WWII for obvious reasons.

Title: What is bigger?
Question: what is bigger, the atom or the ion?
Answer: Positive ions are smaller than the atom.\nNegative ions are larger than the atom.\n\nThe reason is that a positive ion is created by removing an electron from the atom and removing an electron means that the remaining electrons effectively see a larger nuclear charge causing them to be pulled in closer to the core (there are fewer electrons to "screen" the core)\nOn the other hand a negative ion is created by adding an electron and there are then more electrons to screen the core and the size increases.

Question: What is a traveling violation in basketball?
Answer: The traveling violation occurs when a player, who is in possession of the ball, moves his (or her) feet without bouncing (or "dribbling") the ball at the same time. A player is allowed to lift his heel, but his toes and the ball of his foot must remain fully planted, so that they are only "pivoting" or swiveling around, without moving to another position on the floor.\n\nIn the NBA, the traveling rule is probably the rule most frequently violated without being called. Players on the move towards the basket frequently take "extra steps" without being called for it - but the relative freedom to violate the traveling rule is what has changed basketball from the old-time game of "set shot" shooting (standing still) to the more exciting modern game of "driving" and "dunking".

Question: Calculate the molecular mass:8.02g of solute in 861g of water lower the freezing point to -0.430c?
Answer: O.k., so you are given the final temperature (-0.430 C). Since the freezing point of water is usually O degrees C, the temperature decrease is 0.43 degrees C. Like in the other problem, let's set up some dimensional analysis.

(0.43 deg.C decr)*(1 mole compound / 1.86 deg.C decr) = X

Here X would equal 0.23 moles compound

Next, you want to find the grams of solute in solution.

(8.02g solute/0.861 kg solvent) = Y

Y here is equal to 9.31 g compound/kg solution

Now that you have the mass in grams and the number of moles of the solute, you can divide Y by X, which gives the units for molecular mass (g/ mol.)

The answer should be around 40.48 g/mol. The solute cannot be determined from this information because no additional information is given concerning what is most likely a compound (not a pure element).

Question: how does a touch light work, is the person touching the light acting as the ground?
Answer: Touch-sensitive lamps almost always use a  property of the human body -- its capacitance. The word "capacitance" has as its root the word "capacity" -- capacitance is the capacity an object has to hold electrons. The lamp, when standing by itself on a table, has a certain capacitance. This means that if a circuit tried to charge the lamp with electrons, it would take a certain number to "fill it." When you touch the lamp, your body adds to its capacity. It takes more electrons to fill you and the lamp, and the circuit detects that difference. It is even possible to buy little plug-in boxes that can turn any lamp into a touch-sensitive lamp. They work on the same principle.

Title: Interview Help-  just scored an interview that I really want. I really need help on not screwing this up?
Question: I stopped working about a year ago. I told my boss that I was unhappy and I wanted to tell her that I was in the process of looking for another job. I told her that I intended to use my lunch breaks and half-days to go on interviews and I did not anticipate leaving for about 6 months.I never resigned. I did this because I needed the money until I found another job, and so she would not be stranded by me giving her only 2 weeks.

Less than a month later I came into work, went into my office and all of my stuff was boxed up and there was someone at my desk on my computer- deleting and copying files. Everyone was shocked to see me there. I logged onto another computer and received and email which stated it was officially my last day with the company. 

I made an unemployment claim and was given compensation for the 6 months I intended to stay there.

What do I say at the interview? Was I fired, laid off, or did I quit? Is this too much drama for a prospective employer?
Answer: Well to start off, congratulations for being totally upfront and honest with your former employer about leaving the company.  Even though it seems you were punished for this, it was totally the right thing to do; you have nothing to be ashamed of or anything to feel that you should hide, which you would have had if you had been sneaky or deceitful.  So, that is something a new employer should definitely take into consideration.
If I were in your spot, I would be up front and honest about the situation without tearing apart the former boss or company.  I quit my job back inJanuary due to physical and emotional stress, and am just now trying to find a job.  It's taken me that long to get over the damage done to my heart.  I have asked prospective employers to not speak with my former employer, and I tell them the truth:  that it was a very hostile environment and that I am not comfortable with anyone at that company knowing what is going on in my life.  I have, however, given references of people who worked there when I did that are no longer there that I am okay with.  The two places I have been interviewed this week were very understanding.  Mostly, they appreciated my honesty.  But, I was also careful to not tear apart anybody, either.  I think that helped.
If you let them know your version of what happened while being respectful of the people involved and they call your old boss who lets her mouth run off about what a louse you are and drags your reputation through the mud and they choose to listen to her, it's probably not the place for you to be anyway.  Chances are they will compare your respectfulness to her disrespect and you'll win out anyway.  In any case, you'll be able to look at yourself in the mirror the next day, knowing you have done the right thing, no matter the outcome. 
Best wishes!

Title: Inclusion for Special Education?
Question: Does anyone have any information on inclusion for special education students (websites, personal experiences, etc...)
Answer: Inclusion is when students with a need for individiualized instruction are included in the regular classroom and receive the services they need within the classroom setting.  This may be for some or all classes.

Students who are mainstreamed are most often students with mild to moderate learning or emotional disabilities.  They will have an invoiivualized education plan (IEP) written by a team of people concerned about his/her educational progress.  That team generally incudes special education teacher, regular education teachers, specialists such as speech therapists, parents and representatives from any community service providing agencies.

The IEP will include modifications and accomodations that may be made within the general education setting to allow the student to thrive.  These may be as simple as untimed tests and seating near the teacher, to having the teacher wear a special sound ampligfication device, among others.

Does inclusion work?  Well, that depends on the school district's commitment to inclduing kids in the regular classroom, on the students (and parents') willingness to meet some general classroom expectations, and upon the skill of the classroom teacher.  If everyone works together and expects success, it generally happens.  If any member of the instructional team doubts the child's ability to succedd, it usually becomes a self-fulfilling prohecy, and the child may end up back in a separate special education setting. This special environment is viewed as being a more restictive environment, whereas the incluusion class is viewed as a less restrictive environment, as required by the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA).

My third grader has surprised some naysayers and has been included in regular education for math and special subjects for two years now.  I also enjoy helping students reach their academic goals.

I hope this answers your question.

Answer:

Title: Binding energy?

Answer: H=Mass of Hydrogen atom=Mass of proton + Massof electron [Since Hydrogen atom contains 1 electron & 1 proton]
n=mass of neutron

Binding energy is defined as the min. amt. of energy reqd to break the nucleus into its constituents ie. proton and neutron.

Binding energy=Mass defect X 931 Mev [Million or Mega electron volt]

Mass defect={Atomic number X mass of proton+ [Atomic Mass number-Atomic number] X mass of neutron}-actual observed mass of nucleus.
           ={Mass of Hydrogen atom + [Atomic Mass number-Atomic number] X mass of neutron}-Observed [Isotopic] mass of atom

Title: Is "intelligent design" a valid scientific concept? (read more)?
Question: Please read this carefully...

Does it rise to the level of a scientific theory?
Or even a hopothesis?
Why or why not?

This link may help:
http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index;_ylt=AtPspx5CqzU_htGM1fYTrRLsy6IX?qid=1006040717662
Answer: No, it really isn't.

The fundamentals of intelligent design are basically anti-science.  The sole argument used in its support is to cease thinking about any subject which is not immediately understood.

"That feature of life looks hard to evolve, therefore, Unnamed Intelligent Designer did it."

I like to look at how history would be different if the great scientists of the past had used such logic.

Isaac Newton:  "Gravity pulls things down, but the moon stays up.  How strange.  Must be God."  (Nobody works out the laws of physical motion.)

Edward Jenner:  "I wonder why milkmaids get smallpox less seriously than other people... Oh, I guess God did it."  (Nobody invents vaccines.)

Intelligent Design "theory" is the death of science.  It is lazy thinking.  It is simply accepting any unknown as an unknown and finding nothing in it worth investigating further.  It is the most fundamentally anti-science idea possible.

Think my examples of overstated?  Consider the real life guru of the ID movement, Michael Behe.  He testified in court that nobody could figure out the evolution of the immune system.  When he was presented with dozens and dozens of articles working out the evolution of the immune system, he admitted having read none of them, but had no compunction about just declaring it "wasn't enough".  How much would be?  Here is a person who has stopped thinking.  He's supposed be a biochemist, but he has no interest in expanding biochemistry.  He found a gap and declared that God filled it and his thoughts stopped there.  Many, many other scientists, unencumbered by the albatross of ID continued to investigate and have expanded our knowledge of the immune system extensively, just so Behe can sit back smugly and declare whatever progress they've made cannot possibly be enough.

I repeat, ID is the death of science.  ID is the most fundamentally anti-science idea possible.

ID "theory" is best stated, "It is absolutely undeniable that someone, somewhere, at some point, did some thing, using some methods, to create life."  That's not a theory.  That hardly qualifies as an idea!  But they can't fill in any of the vapidity.  If they fill in any of the unknowns, it becomes obvious they're trying to force their religion onto the masses.  Therefore, they're stuck with a vague framework of an idea.

If they could fill in bits, they might stumble into a theory that was testable.  If we replace "someone" with "My great grandmother", suddenly, we have an idea we can test.  A false idea, but still a testable one.  My great grandmother has identifiable properties.  We know how much biochemistry she knew.  We can judge the likelihood of her having done such a thing.  That likelihood is, of course, so close to zero there's little point in calculating it.

If we fill in the "how" gap with "using a screwdriver", then again, we can test it.

But ID theory refuses to fill in the gaps.  It claims to not be interested in who.  It claims to not be interested in where, when, how or what.  Dembski says it's a theory of "design detection".  But, again, how do we test it?

Dembski's filter resolves to two states:  Yes, it was designed!  We don't know.

So, can this be falsified?  Can we send something designed through and have the filter produce a false negative?  No, because the filter has no negative state.  It doesn't say "designed/not designed", it says "designed/don't know".  There is no way to test for a false negative.

Can we test for a false positive?  Nope.  Since God is on the table here (and they refuse utterly to let natural laws have sway like real science does), everything in the universe supposedly could be designed.  So there is nothing that you can definitively say isn't designed to run through the filter.

Question: What can you tell me about thermal insulation?
Answer: Thermal insulation blocks the movement of heat.

Typical thermal insulations are spun glass or fiber glass that traps air.  Trapped dead air is a very good insulator because it prevents convection transfer of heat.

A vacuum is also a good insulator and that is how a thermos bottle works.

Styrafoam is another excellent insulator.

The higher the R value on an insulating product, the more heat that it will block.

Consider this temperature gradient and heat flow:

Outside it is 5ºF.  Inside it is 70ºF.  Over the span of 4 to 6" in a normal wall, the temp gradient is 65 degrees!  What prevents all that heat from rushing outside?  Good insulation of R13-R19 in the wall.

Question: What is the exact definiton of incomplete dominance?
Answer: Incomplete dominance refers to the situation where a gene has 2 alleles that are equally dominant. There is not a dominant and a recessive gene. Furthermore in incomplete dominance, when both dominant alleles are present in the chromosomes, neither will show up; instead you get a blend of both characteristics. For example in the four o'clock flower, the petal colors white and red exhibit the condition of incomplete dominance. When both white and red alleles are prseent, the result is a pink flower; pink of course being a blend between red and white.

Title: I have a pimple on my chin, big! but it isn't like a pimple, its like a inside lump.swollen it did go now?
Question: but, i thought it was a spider bit but i dont think so,its like ingrow,big lump. , have u ever got this?? 
, what should i do to make it go away ,,,fast...how did i get this!!!!!!
Answer: Okay there are several possibilities here.  One is cystic acne, HOWEVER, if you have not had cystic acne before it would be very unusual for it to start now and for you to have only one spot effected! (fyi, cystic acne is aka underground pimples and do not come to a "head" easily and often leave scars).  Two, this could be an ingrown hair. This is much more common in males who shave but can occur in females as well. The hair literally has been covered with epidermis (top layer of skin) and is growing inward which causes a local inflammatory reaction/infection.  Third, an abscess caused by a local infection.  Now, to be technically correct all of the above, including a basic pimple, are abscesses (pus filled lesions). I am differentiating by cause be it a cystic pimple, ingrown hair or secondary infection (i.e. a scratch).

Treatment: "Let the 'evil' humours out!" 
In other words..."release the pus!"  Most teenagers are adept at this by squeezing their 'zits,' but the type of lesion/lump you have will not simply erupt with squeezing. If anything, you risk making it worse! So what do you do? Well, you can try: 
1) Direct heat with a wash cloth soaked in the hottest water you can stand without burning yourself and an astringent such as Witch Hazel.  This will, hopefully, bring the lesion to a 'head' (a whitish or thin dome on top) at which point it is ready for extruding (i.e. a good squeeze to release the pus)!) 2) Apply antibiotic cream or ointment 3 times a day along with a secondary antibiotic like Oxy 10 (this will hopefully reduce the size by fighting the infection). 3) Finally, IF the lump is indeed pus filled and not simple induration (inflammatory response that precedes the pus stage) you need it drained. IF you are lucky and step number one allowed you to get rid of the pus (that white/yellow nasty stuff that you get out of pimples) then, Great! BUT, if you have an ingrown hair or the secondary infection then you will need 'surgical' drainage and treatment of the underlying problem. In other words, a doctor needs to lance the lump with a scalpel. DON'T STRESS! This is done with a bit of local anesthetic and a quick stab with a small surgical blade which releases the pus and you instantly feel much better! You may need oral antibiotics such as cephalexin or sulfa or clindamycin or doxicycline as well as topical (skin applied) antibiotics to treat the infection. The doctor may remove the ingrown hair if that is the cause.

Bottom line: IF the lump does NOT come to a head or does not recede with topical treatment then you need to see your doctor for definitive care. Don't stress! The treatment is FAR better than the alternative of a worsened infection that could, RARELY, lead to admission to the hospital for major IV antibiotics and surgery.  Treat it early and aggressively!

ALSO, Since I know that people with pimples may be reading this...PLEASE be careful in squeezing pimples in the 'T' zone. This is the area from the tip of your nose to the forehead from between your eyebrows! The drainage system of this area leads DIRECTLY toward your brain!  I am not joking in relating the following anecdote: I had a patient DIE of a pimple! He squeezed one in this T zone and the infection spread to his brain and he died of cerebritis (brain infection) despite aggressive treatment!

USE topical antibiotics or see your doctor if you have a 'zit' that gets bigger in this 'T' Zone or has worsened redness of the surrounding skin (aka Cellulitis).

Good Luck!

Greg M.D.

Title: Monarchs and Milkweed question?
Question: Apparently, Monarch butterfly caterpillars are poisonous to  most would be predators because of the protection conferred upon them due to feeding on milkweed.  If it is correct that Monarch butterflies' survival has been enhanced by this selective adaptation (by their larvae being able to tolerate the toxins in milkweed), and this gave them a competitive advantage in the natural world, then why aren't milkweeds crawling with all sorts of other species of caterpillars gaining similar protection?  In other words, why did only Monarch caterpillars hit on this means of protection from predation, when other butterflies and their larvae could have also adapted to milkweed?  If the Monarch butterly gained this tolerance to milkweed through a chance mutation, then why did chance favour *only* the Monarch butterfly and not other butterflies..?
Answer: It's not that they're poisonous but they taste very bitter because they sequester certain chemicals from milkweed. Once a young bird eats one monarch, it never eats another. And actually not all monarchs taste that bitter - but enough to eventually convince most birds to look elsewhere. \n\nThe ability of insects to detoxify or sequester plant chemicals is not a random mutation or even a fixed thing. The plant made the chemicals to deter insect feeding (that is, plants with bitter tasting foliage survived when others did not, so now most of the plant population is bitter). Insects then evolved methods to detoxify these chemicals (that is, the caterpillars that could stomach the taste survived and the genes that allowed this behavior multiplied in the population). The process is known as coevolution and takes millennia. Insects are quite often specific to just one type of plant - they grow up together (evolutionarily speaking) and are constantly changing but at a rate we humans can not readily see.

Answer: KWANZAA Is the first non-heroic African American holiday ever to come Into existence. Blacks, from every phase of life in the United States, have been practising this holiday since 1965. This warm, social, holiday where people gather to reinforce each others spirit and friendship was founded by Professor Maulana Karenga.
Celebration of this holiday lasts for seven days from December 26 to January 1.
It is a holiday based on the African celebration of the "first fruits harvest" which comes at the end of their year, and KWANZAA lasts seven days to promote the seven basic principles honored during this holiday.

1. Unity - 2. Self determination - 3. Collective work and responsibility 4. Co-operative economics 5. Purpose 6. Creativity & 7. Faith

At KWANZAA gatherings people usually bring fruit or food and share a meal and a smile. The unity cup is passed and people say positive things about Blacks and our future. Then the candles are lit, and something is said about each principle. After that people dance or talk, and just have a good time. There's a lot more to this holiday than superficial gift giving. It's a time to lift each other up and give thanks for being of a unique culture with a value all its own.

They also have a stamp that was created by Synthia St. James who was born in Los Angeles... She is an author of childrens and adult books, artist and has a line of her own clothing

Laws against "usury" go back to biblical times and were adopted by states starting in the 18th century. The concept was simple: People in dire need of money will pay just about any interest rate to get it. So society moved to protect them from sleazy lenders who threaten to break legs.

In New York, for instance, it's a crime for an individual to charge more than 25% interest on a loan. But what's illegal for a loan shark in New York is perfectly legal for credit card issuers that put their operations in states that have no rate ceilings, such as South Dakota and Delaware. They can charge their customers everywhere whatever they wish, because what counts is the law of the state where their credit card operations are based.

Question: i want to know how to be successful in job interview?
Answer: 1. Learn as much as you can about the company you are applying to, and if possible, learn about the division/dept. you will be working for.

2. Try to intuit what they want to hear. It isn't that you want to tell them what they want to hear - interviewers are smart, and know when they are being played. But by knowing what characteristics they are looking for, you know how to emphasize those spots on your resume that align with that.

3. Be prepare to be quizzed on work scenarios, ethical scenarios, hypothetical teamwork challenges. Try and formulate answers in advance to typical hypothetical workday issues that might be raised.

4. Don't sit until your interviewer asks you to take a seat.

5. Do as much listening as you can. While a good interviewer is there mostly to listen and not to talk, the good interviewee will often do the same. Don't be silent - if asked a question, answer it. But take the opportunities you do have to listen, and pay attention. What you are told will work to your advantage, if you are paying attention - it will make you seem alert if you make clear you have absorbed it.

6. Don't fidget or show signs of anxiousness. Channel your nervous energy into being animated and appearing interested and/or excited.

Title: if you have had negative items deleted off your credit report?
Question: What did you do to do it?
How many disput letters did it take?

did any tatic help you more than others?
Answer: Yes, I have helped many, many people do this.  First know that the bureau must verify any debt you dispute.  If they can not verify it, it must be deleted.  They have 30 days to do this.

With 7 years in the credit business, I recommend disputing them all at the same time, as you will likely need to go through several rounds of letters to get what you want done. If something is blatently wrong with your credit report, call the bureau after they write back and refuse to remove it. Go up the food chain until a manager agrees to remove or amend the incorrect info on the spot. Don't buy into their speach about re-disputing it - but make sure you have provided the information necessary by mail already to correct the error. It will not help you to insist on something being removed if you have not provided verificaiton on why.

When you mail in the dispute letter, mail in as much information as possible with it. If your verification is a bankruptcy, send in all the pages to your petition and tab the important pages for them to review.

Also mail in a copy of an electric bill and a copy of your ID to avoid any delays. See the FTC web's site for your specific rights with collectors and debt reporting:

http://www.ftc.gov/

If your problem is directly with the creditors, write to them ONE time. If they do not remove incorrect information, write to your state's attorney general's office and the FTC. This will get you the results you seek if you are in the right.

If this is a collection agency problem, write to the same people plus the ACA at www.acainternational.org. Collection agencies are generally slime, so know your rights before you call them. See your rights here:

http://www.ftc.gov/bcp/conline/edcams/credit/index.html

If you have legit items that are bad, dispute them also. If they can not be verified, they must be deleted. It is not your responsibility to prove they are inaccurate, it is the credit bureaus who must demonstrate they are.

Hope this helps!

The water-cement ratio is a critical factor in the design of concrete mixes.

Question: Two point-source loudspeakers are a certain distance apart, and a person stands 12.0 m in front of one of them on a line perpendicular to the baseline of the speakers. Answer: Ley y be the non zero seperation. Then minimum nonzero separation so that the observer hears little or no sound is given by  
            y = {(2n+1)vD}/2fd 
where v = 340 m/s
      D = 12 m
      d = distance b/w loud speakers
      f = 1000 Hz

Take n = 0

      y = 2.04/d m ( here d is not given)

Title: muscle soreness after running?
Question: I ran twice two weeks ago on consecutives days (most of it down hill) and have been having muscle soreness in my calves and behind my knees ever since.  No, I  had not run much before those two days and not stretched before.  I also have been experimenting with orthodics in my shoes ever since hoping that might cure the problem but could it have made it worse? I want to continue to exercise, actually my muscles hurt less when I keep moving, how should I proceed?
Answer: Hi! I'm a certified personal trainer with 10 years experience. I am wondering if you'd been running prior to this? Did you just decide to take up running then do 2 days in a row? Running is a high impact sport. It is best alternated with lower-impact activiities. Whether you were running before or not, it is better to run every OTHER day and let your muscles get some recovery time. Muscles don't get stronger with exercise, they get stronger AFTER exercise, during the recovery period. Rest is essential to muscle growth and fitness advancement. Doing light workouts on the days between allows more blood flow to the overworked muscles and speeds up recovery time. Taking 1000 IU's of vitamin E has also been shown to reduce muscle soreness by repairing muscle oxidation on a cellular level. Running 3 days per week is excellent for cardio fitness, but every day of the week ABOVE 3, increased your chance of injury by 100%.  I would recommend talking with a trainer who has a certification from ACE, NASM, ACSM or NSCA. Those are the 4 best certifications out there. There are more than 200 others that are just paper. Let them design you a program. Some trainers will even do some muscle tests on you to find out if you have muscle imbalances or problems. The orthodics might be hurting you, not helping. Please seek professional advice. It could save you some serious injury for a very small price.

Title: what is shuck n jive?
Question: what does this mean, exactly?
Answer: "To shuck and jive" originally referred to the intentionally misleading words and actions that African-Americans would employ in order to deceive racist Euro-Americans in power, both during the period of slavery and afterwards.  The expression was documented as being in wide usage in the 1920s, but may have originated much earlier.\n\n"Shucking and jiving" was a tactic of both survival and resistance.  A slave, for instance, could say eagerly, "Oh, yes, Master," and have no real intention to obey.  Or an African-American man could pretend to be working hard at a task he was ordered to do, but might put up this pretense only when under observation.  Both would be instances of "doin' the old shuck 'n jive."\n\nToday, the expression has expanded somewhat from earlier usage, and is now sometimes used to mean "talking pure baloney," "goofing off," or "goofing around."  The original meaning of deceit often remains, however.

Title: What's the correct way to say 'to vacuum' in German? Ich sauge...Staub, or Ich staubsauge, or neither?
Question: This question came up in German class. An answer would be appreciated
Answer: Staubsaugen - infinitive form - to vacuum

Example

Ich muß meinen Teppich staubsaugen.
I have to vacuum my carpet

It might be better to stick with the verb to clean:

Ich säubere meinen Teppich mit einem Vakuum
I clean my carpet with a Vacuum

Vacuum is one of those nouns that is used colloquially as a verb like zerox.  In German, it can't be used as a verb per se.

Title: what is a creatine kinase?
Question: I have a presentation to do on creatine kinase and the format given by my instructor is to start with the introduction,  general information,basic biochemistry/ isoenzyme separation, determination method/ diagnostic principle, clinical significance,specimen of choice, reference level and conclusion.
Answer: Creatine is an organic acid that acts as phosphate storage in cells (such as busy muscle cells) where the ATP:ADP ratio might get too low. A kinase is always an enzyme that phosphorylates something, that is, it adds a phosphate group. So creatine kinase is an enzyme that catalyses the phosphorylation of creatine to store phosphate, and the reverse reaction to transfer the phosphate back to ADP to form ATP.

Question: I have a number 2 lead pencil, was there ever a number 1 or 3?
Answer: Yes.  They represent different grades of pencil.  I do a lot of pencil sketching and use many grades of pencil depending on the need and effect I'm looking for.

It's been my experience that the softer grades are great for contrast and shading. They're also good for darkening large areas of a drawing.  They do tend to "cake up" and smudge easily if too much is applied.

The harder grades are great for fine lines and when exact detailing is required.  They can hold a razor sharp point longer too.  Harder grades are okay for light shading but not very good when there's a need for a lot of high contrast darkening.

The following link shows a visual grading scale for reference.

Question: why is salt use to melt the snow?
Answer: Couple good answers there. The ones about lowering the freezing point are good, but not quite there. If it just lowered the freezing point (which is true) it would never melt the ice/snow, since it nothing has affected the temperature yet. What happens is that the first interaction of salt and ice/snow (water) causes heat to be released, it is an exothermic reaction. That little bit of heat allows more ice to melt, reacting with more salt, creating more heat, melting more ice, etc. So it is the exothermic reaction that causes the melting, the lower freezing point keeps it from refreezing.

Title: a planetary nebula exists before what?
Question: before the red giant phases.\nbefore the main sequence.\nfor a long duration compared to the time the star spent on the main sequence.\nor all the above.
Answer: A Planetary Nebula is a misleading name.  At the end of a lower mass star's life (for stars up to about 8 times the mass of the sun), the star puffs up, and loses the outer layers of gas surrounding it.  All this gas goes out into space where it can be seen as what we call a planetary nebula.\n\nOriginally the word "nebula" was applied to any astronomical object that was not a star or a memeber of our solar system (planets, asteroids etc), the word essentially means "cloud."\n\nAs telescopes got better people started to find many different types of nebulae. A Spiral Nebula looks like, well a spiral, today we know that these are spiral galaxies.  Planetary Nebula were named because the looked round, and a number of them had the same greenish color that Uranus had been seen to have by Hershel.

at controlling malaria, quite apart from the harm it
does to nonpest species.  The mosquitoes have
become resistant to the pesticides, just as the
malaria parasite has become resistant to the
medications used to kill them.  Furthermore, when
a mosquito population has become resistant to
one kind of pesticide it usually can develop a
resistance to another pesticide more quickly.

be developed to replace the indiscriminate use
of pesticides.

Title: i would like to know how to write a good budget?
Question: i want to learn to write a good budget
Answer: A good budget is one you that makes sense for you.

First you need something to save for, new shoes, car, vacation, retirement etc.

Now you have items to save for place a dollar value next to them and a time frame. For example: New shoes $120 12 months = $10 a month.

You will have in your budget items that are considered 'fixed' items - like rent/mortgage, utilities, gas/transportation, etc.

Line your fixed items up, then your goals under that, next to all of them will be your monthly figure. Once you have a total, you subtract that from your net(in pocket) pay.

You will either have money left over OR you will not have enough - this is when you need to rework your budget - for example: New shoes $120 2 years (24 months) = $5 and so on.

I have used new shoes, but of course it can be anything that is important to YOU.

Please consider, as part of your budget, money for emergencies. Six to twelve months of FIXED living expenses (or somewhere in between ) is a good number. This (emergency fund) may take you a while, but it will be well worth it when you have an emergency.

If you have a preadsheet program, Xcel or any other, this will make the calculations easier - as it will recalculate as you change items.

Good luck!

Answer:

Question: I'm an agnostics, whom believes generally in evolution, but I find the common explanation a bit far-fetched or rather I just can't picture it.

The short answer is that I doubt it's possible in this kind of forum to get into enough details to convince a confirmed *creationist* that humans evolved from simpler life forms. After hearing people's arguments and questions for many years, I am convinced that there are six huge factors getting in the way of a general acceptance of the *overwhelming* scientific evidence for evolution.  

1 - the common misconception that evolution claims apes or chimpanzees changed to human beings, and the perceived indignity -- and indignation -- that goes along with that idea... or with *any* suggestion that we evolved from a lower form.  It's nothing but ridiculous human arrogance!
2 - the lack of human conception for the vast time life has had on Earth to evolve
3 - the human temptation to rush things and jump to ridiculous (and therefore naturally hard to believe) conclusions.  Evolution involves not three or four steps, like fish to amphibian to ape to human!)... not hundreds, or even thousands of big, visible steps... but perhaps hundreds of millions of minute, subtle changes in a life form.  Remember, we have had the time!
4 - the mistaken notion that creatures evolved because they "decided" to, or "wanted" to.  When we say, for example, that fish needed to absorb oxygen more efficiently from the water, so they evolved gills, that's not to imply it was a choice.  Evolution is about mutations... changes that were random from one generation to the next, over long periods of time.  Those changes that happened to be good for the creature meant that creature survived long enough to reproduce, which meant there would now be lots of little babies with that same feature.
5 - a fearful and/or stubborn refusal to abandon faith in a Creator, since doing so might condemn the unbeliever to eternal suffering
6 - It's just *easier* to think about a Creator.

Answer: A healthy diet consists of a variety of food groups....let me be specific. It is recommended (Canada's food guide) that you eat 1900-2200 calories per day. ;Broken down even further, the food guide suggests:
7 fruits/vegetables
7 grains
3 dairy products
2 meat/alternatives
6 fats (1 fat serving is every 5g of extra oil, butter, you get the picture)
This combination of food equals roughly 2000 cal. (try not to get caught up in the numbers, this will only make you crazy)
Also, try eating this combination of food in the form of 3 meals and 3 snacks. Every meal and snack should consist of a carbohydrate source (such as fruit/vegetables, grains) and a protein source (dairy or meat). This combination helps you to feel full and satisfied (as well as keeps your metabolism working) throughout the day. Try aiming for 2 food groups for snacks and at least three food groups for meals. Always try to eat breakfast within the first half hour of waking up then have a snack about 2 and a half hours later, then lunch 2 and a half hours later then.....you get it, this way until bed time snack. Title: Importance of limiting reagents?
Question: Why is it important to have a limiting reagent when performing a lab experiment? and why is it not simpler to make both reactions go to completion?
Answer: In some cases, when the reaction rate is fast, and the reaction goes all the way to completion, one uses the stoichiometric amounts necessary to convert all of reactants.  But most real-world reactions aren't like that.  The reaction rate tends to slow down as product is created.  If one used just the right amounts of reactants to produce the theoretically possible amount of product, one might wait a very long time, or forever: many reactions just reach an equilibrium, and never go to completion.  So, you use a large excess of one of the reactants, which causes all, or almost all, of the other reactant to be converted.

Title: How do we earn the trust and get our parents to believe us and let us see more of each other and understand?
Question: I'm 17, shes 16.
we have been goin out for 6months
we only talk for about a halfhour a day
we only hang out about twice a week at most
we dont do anything bad ever!, which they think we do all time
parents say they like her, hers say they like me, they say everythings goin to fast and we see to much of each other.
sometimes we come home late from movies and we both get yelled at alot for no reason because they "think" we were doin something bad, which we NEVER are. 
I love her to death and dont wanna loose her because of our parents, i dont know what to do.
I just want the trust and wish both of our parents would understand that we dont do what they think we do, i wish they would understand. 
They just think we lie about everything.
I juss want some advice on how to get the understanding and trust.
Answer: From my experience, coming home late or breaking curfew was a major way of testing my parents trust. Considering your ages, I am surpised that your parents are so restrictive. Ask yourself, what is this 'bad' that they think you're doing? Did your parents come from deeply religious families? Were your parents also restricted by their parents? What about her parents? It may not be fair, or make a whole lot of sense these days, but that could explain some of their methods. Do you or your girlfriend have troubled pasts, maybe trouble with the law? Did you ever have a truancy problem with school? Don't think that I am blaming their behavior on you, I just want you to think of all  possibile reasons. It almost sounds like you two live a bit far away from eachother, and that might explain why you're only allowed to see eachother twice a week, and talk on the phone for only half an hour a day. Have I nailed it yet? No? Okay, parents may not seem to make any sense some of the time, but they are your parents. Like it or not they have say into your relationships. The more you show respect for them and their wishes, usually the more trust they'll have for you. So if you're considering sneaking around after dark or anything like that, don't try it. Chances are you'll get caught, and just imagine how often you'd get to see her then? Probably not at all. I know this is a hard time for you both, you're almost legal adults, but until you turn the magic age of 18, you just have to bite down and endure this. You will get through this, just be patient with her and your parents. I am going to assume that talking with your parents wont make much of a difference, but there is nothing wrong with trying. Ask them what it is that they fear so much, and do your best to put that fear to rest. Assure them that you intend to follow their wishes, and do so when you're out with her. If they see that you're true to your word, the less likely they are to shorten the leash. I get the feeling that their fear is your sexual activity. It is my personal opinion that you two are at the ages when your sexuality is your business, however a parent will feel like your business is always their business. You can be 50 years old, and they'll still consider you their baby. Being that your sexuality is your business, I hope you wont mind if I give you a piece of advice: protect you and your girlfriend and use a condom every time. Anyway, you will get through this, I promise. Good luck.

Question: Im after Snowboard Binding, whats best the ratchet or the step in effect? Much like the FLOW label?
Answer: Okay, I've been Snowboarding for over twenty years, worked for a snowboard company (Avalanche Snowboards/Universal Bindings) where I was the Assistant Binding Production Manager for 4 years, spent 4 years as a snowboard rental shop manager and now manage a Winter Sports Retail Store.

Please, don't believe the hype that step-in bindings are dangerous. That is completely and utterly untrue. With proper care and maintenance they are just as safe as the traditional ratchet bindings. People find them a bit more inconvenient than the ratchet type as they are susceptible to clogging with snow, the boots are usually either too stiff or too soft and there are fewer choices of boots to choose from. They are very popular with rental shops as they are much more durable, dependable and fit a wide range of boot sizes more easily than ratchet types. Also, crossover boarders  (former skiers) particularly older ones find it more similar to what they were used to on ski's and find them easier on their backs as there is less bending over. Keep in mind that Step-in bindings are becoming less and less popular and many manufacturers have stopped production on them.

I prefer ratchet bindings myself. I like Burton P1 Carbons and I'm really excited to try out Burton's CO2's next season. I've ridden flow bindings and I don't like them as much. They are very easy to use and very comfortable but I cannot get them tight enough to get the response I am use to. I run a very stiff set-up with my P1 Carbons and Driver X boots. I have talked to tons of people who really like Flow bindings but they just aren't for me.

Always be honest with yourself about your skill level and style of riding when purchasing equipment. If all you do is cruise intermediate runs then you don't need the craziest, most high performance setup on the planet. You'll be much happier with equipment designed for your or just slightly above your ability level. Companies like Burton, Drake, Tech 9, Flow, Ride and K2 all make quality products.

Given a choice, get a binding with as many adjustment options as possible. I have found that not all bindings fit the same and the more choices you have to make a binding fit your boot better the more comfortable you will be.

Hope that helped.

Answer:

Title: How about this riddle?
Question: A Man carries some dollars in his pocket and goes to the church and prays, Oh Jesus, Please double my dollars and I shall donate eight of those to the church. He checks his pocket and finds that dollars have been doubled by Jesus. As promised he donates eight of the dollars to the church. Then he goes to the second church makes the same prayer there also. Here also his dollars are doubled and he donates eight of the dollars. Then he goes to the third church and repeats the same prayer and to his utter surprise, his dollars are doubled in third church also. As promised he makes eight dollars donation there also. But in the third church, when he makes donations, his all dollars are finished. How many dollars did he carry in the begining?
Answer: He has $7\n\nHis money at thew start is X; after the first church, he has 2X (doubled) - 8 (donation); in the second church, (2X-8)*2 - 8; in the third (4X-24)*2 - 8. So since he has no money anymore then, 8X-56 = 0, which makes X=7.

Question: why will old gram-positive cells stain  gram-negative?
Answer: Gram positive cells stain gram positive because of teichoic acid that binds the peptidoglycan layers of the cell walls together. Gram positive cells have 25 to 30 layers of peptidoglycan in their walls, whereas gram negative cells only have one or two layers. As the cells age  their walls start to break down and cannot retain the stain. They lose layers of their peptioglycan or the teichoic acid isn't as effective. I hope that helps.

Title: What do you exactly learn at law school for 3 whole years?
Question: im just curious to know why is there a professional school specifically for law. I mean how would it help me out in my career?
Answer: Law school teaches you more than just "the law," it teaches you how to think like a lawyer.  Legal professions approach problems systematically, and in a way that many people are not used to thinking.  The legal reasoning begins with a rule, then an application to the facts that leads to a conclusion, while people who are not lawyers tend to come to a conclusion, then find facts that support it.\n\nEven though the law changes constantly, you must learn how to research and understand the law.  This is only done through guidance and practice.  Although one can tell what a law is from a statute, a lawyer can find case law to see how the court interpreted it, and find history that may shed light on how it may be applied in the future.  And it takes skills learned over a period of time to learn how to extract the law from a case, or to even find a relevant case.\n\nYou learn research skills, crtitical thinking skills, and ethical standards at law school, along with the fundamentals of major topic areas.  You learn black letter law that will be tested on the bar exam.  You need to attend law school to learn the techniques needed to research law for your client, learn how to write in a legal form, and how to practice ethically.  None of these things can be gained from merely memorizing the law.\n\nIf you are planning to practice law as a career, these are the skills you will need.  For more info on law schools and how to apply, visit http://www.LSAC.org .

Question: why does pubic hair grow to a certain length and then stop?
Answer: There are a lot of kinds of "hair". Each species of mammal has at least one kind of "hair" or fur. Many species have several different specialized types. For example, cat whiskers are very different from regular cat fur in texture and length. One of the main differences in hair is whether it is determinate in length (grows to a certain length and stops) or indeterminate in length (grows for as long as it is alive.) Humans have both kinds in different places on the body. Head hair, scalp and face, is indeterminate. Body hair, arms, underarms, legs, pubic area, fingers and toes is determinate. The only determinate hairs on the head are normal eyebrows, ear hair and nose hairs. I think the reason is obvious. "Wild hairs" are determinate hairs that have encountered a genetic failure. The length possibilities of each type of hair from sheep's wool to seal fur are genetically determined.  Pubic hair is a secondary sex characteristic that signals availability for mating. It is not designed to cover, conceal, protect, or warm the area that produces it. It may have some scent retaining or focusing function too. This is still debatable. I hope this helps.

Question: With work pleez
Answer: 1) Answer: 4y^2z^2/[3x]
8 and 6 are both divisible by 2.
For the variables, subtract the exponent on bottom from the exponent on top.
(4/3)x^(1-2)y^(3-1)z^2
= (4/3)x^(-1)y^2z^2
Since the exponent on x is negative, it must be moved to the bottom.
= (4/3)y^2z^2/x^1
= 4y^2z^2/[3x]

2) Answer: 3p/[5m]
Similar to the first one.

In other words, the PROCESS of accepting and agreeing on laws/customs/religion is socially cohesive.\n\nThe rehabilitation theory of punishment is probably the most socially cohesive because it is based on rehabiliting the criminal so that he can successfully reenter society.

Title: I think I have asthma???
Question: I'm planning on going to the doctor soon... what kind of tests do they run to figure if you've got it or not???
Answer: You probably will have PFT's, Pulmonary Function Tests, where you will breath in and out of equipment that allows the technician to record your lung capacity, and other measurements.  The doctor also will listen to your lungs to determine the extent and kind of weasing, crackles, and other indications.  You probably will have a chest xray (CXR), possibly a CT scan. Be sure you understand what the doctor tells you.  If you are prescribed asthma inhalers, such as Albuterol, Atrovent, Advair, and they don't really help you after a couple of months, then do get another opinion.  I know someone who was told she had adult onset asthma, then also some emphysema.  After three years of getting worse, she went to a university/teaching hospital and found that she had neither.  If you "think" you have asthma, then maybe your symptoms aren't too bad, but they can get much worse.  It's a good idea to keep a time record of significant problems or symptoms for future reference, and for your doc or a new doc.  Also obtain copies of test results to have in case you do go to a new doc.  Hope asthma is all you have, you can still have a basically normal life.

Answer: Gee, kind of hard to work this one out without a complete backgrounder on your entire family history.

But, maybe, you can start out slow, in another week or two. Put a decoration up here or there, make a meal, side dish, or dessert out of your stock of family Christmas favorites.

Some people just get overwhelmed with Christmas and relentless pressure to shop, decorate, be cheery. I don't know if it's urban legend, but I've heard that suicides go up around Christmas. (Not to suggest that's where your mum's heading, just that there are a lot of different pressures and expectations sometimes associated with Christmas.)

Do you know what your mum likes about Christmas? What makes her happy about it, if anything? Maybe it's the shopping, cooking, decorating, eating, seeing friends and family - if you could work those out without being overbearing about quizzing her on it, you might be able to help provide a more happy and comfortable Christmas environment for her.

I've known one or two folks that were most happy at Christmas getting AWAY from family by taking a vacation, preferably in a warm location. It's just that some people have conflicting or negative associations with holidays.

Myself, I like Thanksgiving Day (USA) more than Christmas. I like giving out presents and seeing little kids happy, but Turkey-day just seems more low-key and relaxed.

Oh, and sometimes, as people get older, they just aren't as thrilled with some things as they used to be. I guess it just gets to be old hat or they're focused on things that have gone bad in the past or people that are no longer around, things are no longer the same, etc.

Good luck!

Question: How and where is limestone formed?
Answer: Limestone Formation 101:

1.) Ocean organisms that contain calcium carbonate in their shells (shellfish or forams)die & settle to the bottom of the ocean floor.
2.) At certain depths within the ocean, calcium carbonate begins to dissolve.
3.)Deposits build up over time (millions of years)
4.)Oceans transgress & regress (move inland & back out again) placing layer upon layer down over time.
5.)All the layering & pressure from the ocean above causes the dissolved CaCO3 to harden into rock.
6.)Sometimes pieces of shells are included in the rock (fossiliferous limestone - containing fossils)
7.)Poof...There you have the recipe for limestone.

Title: Why do chemist say that a reaction mechanism is proposed?
Question: Why do chemist say that a reaction mechanism is proposed?
Answer: A mechanism is considered to be proposed, because we can not look at the reaction and follow it in real time.  The reactants are molecules that are too small to see, and the reaction occurs too fast to watch it step by step.  A proposed mechanism accounts for all the observations, such as kinetics, intermediates, catalysts, etc., but can not ever be "proved".

Question: children observations in the math area for 2 year olds?
Answer: The most important activity for a young child is play. That being said, children learn best through play. A child builds mathmatical concepts at a very early age, though they do not know it as "math." You may not even recognize it as math. 

As a child plays with blocks, they are building geometric concepts about shapes and spatial reasoning. They may not even be able to name the shapes, but as they try to build a tower with the blocks, they are using problem solving skills to keep the tower from falling. 

Problem solving also comes into play with such simple activities as hide and seek or memory/matching games. With a memory game, a child learns to think about the tiles they have turned over already, realizing which ones might match. Also, when a child presents a problem to you through play activity, like "I can't do it. How can I...?" Don't just answer it for them. Problem solve with them. Problem solving abilities will be critical for them throughout school.

Reasoning skills are another mathematical concept. These are easily practiced through games and sorting acitvities. Promote this skill by asking questions like:
Are you sure?
How do you know?
Why do you think...?

Foster communication skills. Children must be able to clearly communicate their thoughts in order to explain their steps in solving problems or in trying to understand new concepts. Reading to children is the single most important activity you can do as a parent. Reading skills will help a child in every subject area.

I could go on and on. I guess what I think is most important is to allow your child to play. They will learn and remember what they learn longer.

Title: Is Pete Hautman's book, Invisible worth while reading?
Question: Could you give me a basic overview of the book and also tell me what you thought of it.  I have a choice to read it for extra credit, should I?
Answer: Reviews and Commentary
(http://www.petehautman.com/invisibleinfo.html)  

LIBRARY JOURNAL (starred review) 

Seventeen-year-old Dougie takes everything literally, lacks social graces and is a loner, except, perhaps, for his one friend, athletic and popular Andy Morrow. But readers know almost immediately that something tragic has happened in the recent past: ' Andy and I had some bad luck with fires when we were kids. We're more careful now.' Other students feel threatened by Dougie's disturbing behavior and react by targeting him with cruelty and violence, which only serves to escalate his descent into unreality, isolation, and obsession. The teen has been working for nearly three years on his model railroad set, using 22, 400 headless matches to build a bridge connecting portions of the 'Madham Line.' As his life deteriorates, this obsession and his nightly talks with Andy are the only things that keep him clinging to normalcy. He resists the help of his psychiatrist and hides his medication. Ultimately, he is forced to remember what actually happened on that fateful night. With its excellent plot development and unforgettable, heartbreaking protagonist, this is a compelling novel of mental illness. 

  

HORN BOOK (starred review) 

Gifted in math, and recognizably clever when constructing architectural models (he's building an elaborate railroad system in his basement), Doug reveals that it's human interaction he can't figure out. "I'm a quiet kid, pretty much invisible," he says in a precise, unemotional voice, as this unreliable narrator begins his story. Invisibility is Doug's rationale for explaining a range of rejection, from teacher irritation to peer scorn, particularly from pretty and popular Melissa Haverman, who is disgusted by what readers will recognize as Doug's stalker behavior. But Doug reports one near-perfect relationship, the one he has with his best friend, Andy. Gradually, however, that friendship is revealed to be not what it seems. There are secrets from their past that Doug won't discuss, and hints from their present life that skew his tale. Why is there a strange man in Andy's house? What fuels Doug's increasingly complex rendering of their intertwined initials? What medication is Doug refusing to take? Reading this psychological thriller is much like putting together one of Doug's railroad bridges: connections are being made, but the realities being built may be imitations of life rather than the real thing. The tension comes from entering Doug's private hell and learning what put him there. 

  

PUBLISHERS WEEKLY (starred review) 

The strength of Hautman's painfully sad novel is the wisecracking but clearly unreliable voice of its narrator, 17-year-old Douglas MacArthur Hanson who admits, "I'm not only disturbed, I'm obsessed." One of his passions is "Madham," a town he's building for his model railroad, complete with a 1:800 scale replica of the Golden Gate Bridge. He's also fixated on a pretty girl who clearly wants nothing to do with him. And he's overly reliant on his only friend, Andy Morrow, a fellow junior who is the popular and outgoing yang to Dougie's outcast and introverted yin. Hautman expertly teases out the truth about a tragic incident that occurred "at the Tuttle place" three years earlier, a mystery that propels the story to its horrific conclusion. Dougie is as mathematically gifted and socially inept as the autistic narrator of Mark Haddon's The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time, but he also has a sophisticated wit. During a lapse in conversation at one of his $95-an-hour therapy sessions, he observes, "We stare at each other for about $1.40." His self-deprecating comments and wry observations make his spiral into self destruction all the more heartbreaking. (One measure of how sympathetically the aut

Title: Is the electrical resonant frequency of an object the same or close to its mechanical resonant frequency?
Question: Is there an equation or method (or two different equations or methods) to find the electrical and mechanical frequency of an object?\n\nWhat is the resonant frequency of the Earth (ealectrical and mechanical)?\n\nHow do you tune, modify, and calculate the electrical resonant frequency of a cicuit?
Answer: .  Electrical resonance is not generally related to mechanical resonance.  It would be possible, with considerable calculation and inventiveness to put together a device which vibrated in time with or at a harmonic fraction of its electrical resonant frequency, but it would be a real academic undertaking.\n.  There is no single equation to calculate the resonant frequency of "an object".  If you narrowly define the object as say "a taut string" or "a circular plate", equations of only a few terms can be derived for each of those cases, but the equations would not be the same for different cases.  There would be similarities, but they would have diffent constants and different variables.  Most objects would require the development of a complicated mathematical description of the interelatedness of the masses, elastic properties, dimensions, stiffnesses and coupling mechanics of the various components of the object in order to calculate a resonant frequency.  For some complex objects, which are dominated by a single large and simple structure, like say the cylindrical fuselage of an airplane, there are formulae to calculate the resonant frequency.  For objects like suspension bridges, or cable stayed bridges or skyscrapers, it is necessary to go through the pains of developing a mathematical model to find a range within which the object will resonate.  For most objects, you just build it, test it and then do something to eliminate undesirable resonances.\n.  Pretty much the same can be said about calculating the electrical resonance of an object.\n.  For simple resonant circuits there are straightforward formulae for calculating their resonant frequencies, but the formulae are different for different types of resonant circuits.  Whatever text I might have on resonance of electrical circuits is buried in a box somewhere, but should be able to find a book which includes these formuale and other electrical formulae at a college library, online or maybe even at some place like Radio Shack®.

Answer:

Title: What are the pros and cons of Nuclear thermal propulsion?
Question: Is it feasible to use it in a manned mission to moon?How is it better than nuclear electric propulsion?What will be its harmful effects?Will it violate the NTBT?
Answer: Project Orion was an idea in the 1960s to use nuclear explosions to push a space ship around the solar system. The idea was to use a lot of small explosions in succession to create the sort of effect one gets with a continious burn from the usual chemical fueled rockets.

There were some small scale tests done with non-nuclear nukes, which suggested the concept wasn't crazy, but there was never any full scale tests, and certainly nothing using fission bombs.

It is not clear that scaling this concept up to the size needed for a manned rocket would be that feasible, although some disagree with that assesment. There would be a tremendous stress on the vehicle from all these explosions, especially if they were more contained (in order to harness more of the explosive power for thrust).

But, I don't think we'll ever see anything like this unless there is some sort of mass evacuation of the planet. (Not there is anywhere to go.) As you might expect, a Project Orion rocket is essentially the same as a huge number of atmospheric atomic explosions. Not exactly enviro-friendly, to say the least.

IF by "nuclear thermal" propulsion you mean the generators used by some space probes to generate electricity, then these are far to weak for a manned vehicle. They couldn't supply the power to lift off from Earth, and a trip to the moon using an electric ion drive takes much, much longer than the more direct chemically driven Apollo trajectory. 

Ion propulsion has tried on the space probe Deep Space 1, although this was not nuclear powered.

Title: What makes a good crop for ethanol?

Thanks for sharing your knowledge.
Answer: sugar cane is recognized as having the least trouble creating ethanol. In Brazil this works wonderfully. They have removed the need to import oil and are actually exporting ethanol. In the US sugar cane doesn't grow as well. sugar cane is best in tropical climates. 

In the US corn is the most common for ethanol. It isn't the best crop but is efficient enough for now. Industry best(meaning in the lab) for producing ethanol is above 1 btu of fuel produces 2 btus of ethanol. 

For non-tropical climates cellulose based ethanol is also making big waves. It's advantages are that every living plant tissue is at least 80% cellulose. Dead tissue like wood is around 30 to 40 percent cellulose. A farmer could sell the normal corn seed, and then bale the corn stalks, which are usually left on the ground, for ethanol. Another advantage is that on irrigated and fertilized lands you can grow better than 10 tons of cellulose per acre per season if grown for harvesting cellulose verus the 2.5 tons per acre of corn seed. critiria for a plant for this process is a plant that grows a lost of mass per acre. 

Ethanol is meant to replace gasoline fuel not diesel fuel.
Diesel engines don't have spark plugs, so they can't ignite high octane fuels like gasoline and ethanol. Instead they hammer-strike the better performing low octane deisel fuel. 

Most gas engines out there probably can be converted to work with ethanol. There are a number of conversion kits available. It is likely to work better however if they come from the factory. 

Bio-deisel is wonderful for most diesel engines. I'm afraid I don't know a lot about that topic.

Title: Who discovered irregular galaxies?

Answer: Pierre Méchain\n\nIrregular galaxies are those which do not match the standard Hubble scheme of elliptical, spiral and lenticular galaxies. \nThere's only one irregular galaxy in Messier's catalog: M82, and this one is a distorted disk galaxy. The distortion is due to gravitational interaction with its larger and more massive neighbor M81. \n\nAnother, very similar example is at least mentioned in Messier's catalog, though it did not get a number on its own: NGC 5195, the companion of the Whirlpool galaxy M51, which had been discovered by Pierre Méchain. The only further irregular galaxies known to 1782 are the Large and the Small Magellanic Cloud; these are probably miniature disk galaxies in mutual gravitational interaction, and in interaction with our Milky Way.

Title: Is the NTRP (National Tennis Rating Program) effective at categorizing tennis players?
Question: Does the NTRP, as currently offered by the USTA, categorize tennis players accurately and make competition fair between players? Or, is the NTRP ineffective and require overhaul?\n\njeffspin@comcast.net
Answer: Good question. Unfortunately, there are very mixed motives involved in the current classification system. Those who play in leagues or tournaments usually want the lowest rating they can get so they can win. Those who use the rating to let others know how good they are, usually want to be rated higher.\nIf you are "accurately" rated, you will likely be mismatched against those who fudge. This encourages a downward push such that those who previously might have been 5.0s, for example, are now 4.5s.\nRatings now appear to be based first on your self-assessment, which is frequently falsified, and secondly on your results. I know that players will lose a few matches on purpose just to avoid being moved up a level. This clearly is not in the best interests of the game or in fair competition.\nSo, I do not believe the system is effective in accurately classifying players.

Title: How is  a Magnet made?
Question: Those big MRI machines made me wonder about the construction method of a magnet.
Answer: There are some natural magnets. For example, the mineral magnetite is magnetic, and is found in lodestones. \n\nIf you have a magnet, you can stroke a piece of metal (not all metals, but some) and magnetize it; that is, turn it into a magnet. You line up the magnetic domains when you stroke it so it has a net magnetic field. If you put a radio reciever nearby tuned to the right frequency, you can hear the domains flip as you do this; this is called the Barkhausen effect. \n\nThere are also electromagnets. Passing an electric current through a coiled wire wrapped around the right kind of metal (called a shunt) produces a magnet. This is the kind of magnet one finds in MRI machines.

Title: why is the sky blue?
Question: it's the age old question....
Answer: The sky appears blue because the gases(mainly nitrogen and oxygen) present in our atmosphere vibrate at a specific frequency.  From the light that we can see, ie.. blue, green, red, yellow...etc, the the higher frequency colors are absorbed more by the atmosphere than the lower frequency(actually they're scattered, they still make it to us but indirectly whereas the yellowish color of the sun is more direct).  So blue, green, and violet(violet having the shortest wavelength) are absorbed by the atmosphere, while red, yellow and orange are allowed through.   The color of blue that we perceive the sky varies from day to day based on the content of gases present and the frequency that they vibrate.  It works the same way as light passing through a blue balloon, except in this case the balloon is our atmosphere.

Answer: From wikipedia:\n\nOne often hears the term being applied to the limits that the human body can withstand without losing conciousness, sometimes referred to as "blacking out", or g-loc (loc stands for loss of consciousness). A typical person can handle about 5 g (50 m/s²) before this occurs, but through the combination of special g-suits and efforts to strain muscles —both of which act to force blood back into the brain— modern pilots can typically handle 9 g (90 m/s²) sustained (for a period of time) or more. Resistance to "negative" or upward gees which drive blood to the head, is much less. This limit is typically in the -2 to -3 g (-20 to -30 m/s²) range. The vision goes red and is also referred to as a "red-out". This is probably due to capillaries in the eyes bursting under the increased blood pressure. Humans can survive about 20 to 40 g instantaneously (for a very short period of time). Any exposure to around 100 g or more, even if momentary, is likely to be lethal.

Title: does toyota has its own customer relationship management program?
Question: how the company try to retain its customer?
Answer: Generally car dealerships have customer relationship management (CRM) programs whose goal is to get customers back in for service on their vehicle, buy new cars in a few years, and encourage referrals. These are often part of the large software programs they use to run the dealership. Car manufacturers also try to encourage loyalty by sending out coupons for service specials at local dealerships, for example. The more they can get you at the dealership, the more it will reinforce their name. The point of getting you in for service is establishing the habit of going to the same place for all your automotive needs so that, whenever you decide to purchase a new vehicle, you automatically think to go to the same dealership.

Title: what's hepatitis and wat re d effects?
Question: hepatitis asin d disease. i want to knw hw its contractd. hw dangerous is it?
Answer: Hepatitis is an infection of the liver, usually contracted through sexual contact, sharing of needles, alcohol abuse.  The infection scars the liver and can, in extreme circumstances be fatal but the usual prognosis is general fatigue (flu like symptoms).  There are a number of strains of Hepatitis, some have no long term affects and can be easily treated, others are more serious but can be managed/cured quite easily.  The 1 strain of Hepatitis that can not presently be cured is Hepatitis C - this may lead to serious problems some 15-20 years after contracting it and often goes undiagnosed until such time as one starts to become quite ill.  If you are concerned you may have contracted a type of Hepatitis, ask your doctor for a screening and remember, most forms are easily treated.  Best of luck.

Question: Why is hot air lighter than cold air?
Answer: Hot air is less dense than cold air, assuming that volume is held constant, because the molecules in the heated air move more and faster than in cold air.  Think about a room filled with people.  If the people move around quickly (as molecules in heated air), then the people will spread out more and make more room between eachother (which would be lower density).  Since the hot air is less dense, and more dense objects are "more affected" by gravity, then the warm air is "lighter".

Title: Sexual side effects of birth control pills?
Question: I'v been on the Pill for almost a year now. Everything seemed fine, except more and more I'm becoming less intrerested in sex. My fiance had been in Boot camp and training for the first 6 months of the year, so I didn't really notice a drastic decline of sexual drive. It's put a litle bit of strain on my relationship of 4 years, as we've always had a very nice sex life. I feel bad because my fiance thinks he's doing something wrong(which he's not), but intercourse is not appealing to me lately. Period. I'm considering going off the pill for a while, but I don't want to risk pregnancy(even with using condoms) because I heard you were even more likely to get pregnant soon after coming off it. Has anyone else experienced this side effect? Or do you at least have any suggestions to help me get into the mood?
Answer: That's actually a great question, and yes, I've been on the pill for about 3 years now, and at first I did have that problem. I was on ortho tricyclin, which I blame it on. Because it gradually decreases in strength each week, tricyclin pills tend to have adverse side effects n some people. Once I switched to Yasmin, I think it's called a monocyclin, it all got better. That specific pill gives you the same amount of hormone every day of the month. I've been less moody, and more interested, if you know what I mean. The bad part is that Yasmin does not yet have a generic brand so it is a bit more expensive, but I'd totally recomend it. My doctor switched around my prescription right when I said I was feeling moody. \n\nBut then again, I may be totally off. This article may help: \nhttp://www.twshf.org/pdf/desire_diff_brochure_3_fold_twshf.pdf

Check the on-page factors and be sure to get linked from authority sites in your topic area.

4. Send out press releases. While outfits charge as much as $650 per release, there are free press release submission places on the Web. Press releases allow you to (a) attract media attention; (b) get more back links to your website without sending each website an email request; and (c) get more visibility especially if your press release gets in Google News or Yahoo News.

5. Submit articles. Write articles and submit them to websites accepting author submissions. You get exposure for your business; establishes you as an authority in your field, and allows you to get backlinks for your website. Be sure to have About the Author blurb at the end of the article with your website URL

Answer: As far as stations buying their music.. If the station is in a higher ranking market the record labels will provide the music for free.  They are happy to get the exposure. Some smaller stations sometimes need to actually go out and purchase their music, stations can also subscribe to music services that will provide a basic music library, along with weekly updates.  They will not actually charge the stations for this service, they will do a "barter" service with the stations to place comercials on the stations in leu of chash payments.  I hope I am not confusing you more!  As far as CD's go, a vast number of stations don't even use them anymore.  A lot of stations use a "hard drive" music delevery doing away with all of the clutter of cd's.  Most stations are computer operated these days, a lot of the stations dont even have "live talent" in the studio anymore.  They accomplish this by a process of "Voicetracking".  The DJ does not even have to be in the same city as the station he or she is on.  Talent can e-deliver their voice-tracks to basically anywhere Via a computer.  I hope this helps you out a bit....
