Question: how friction is responsible for reducing the effort required in lifting weights in pulleys?
Answer: My answer is somewhat silly.\n\nI think that is friction between the rope and your hands. If there was low friction, the rope would slide out, or you would have to hold it very very tightly, and this would increase the effort.\n\nAs between the pulley and the rope, there is very little friction and exactly this reduces the effort. If the friction was high (e.g. if the pulley was stuck), the required effort would have been higher.\n\nIf you're interested in how the wheel reduces friction, it is simple. Say you need to pull something by many meters. If there was no wheel, you would have many meters of high friction movement. If you have a wheel with a circumference of 1m, and its axis has a circumference of 1cm, then for each rotation of the wheel (1m) only the axis slides against the wheel by 1cm. The slide distance is 100 times lower. That's even not accounting for sleeve bearings (reducing friction of the axis). Or, even better, ball bearings.

Question: how does A. Einstien come up with the equation E=mc2? how will it be ralative in dev. of a-bomb/fusion?
Answer: The E=mc^2 equations come from Einstein's theory of Special Relativity. Special Relativity concerns the laws of motion and observed properties when objects are travelling very close to the speed of light.

Special relativity starts with two premises: the speed of light is constant for all observers, and the laws of physics are the same for all observers. However, observed properties are not necessarily the same.

Say I flew past the Earth in a space ship travelling 99% the speed of light. To me, the space ship is normal, but the Earth would look squished, rotated, and blue with everyone moving slowly. To you, however, Earth would look normal, but the space ship would be squished, rotated, blue and with everyone moving very slowly. (This gets resolved if the space ship turns around - breaking the symmetry - to come home, and results in the famous Twins "Paradox.")

In describing the laws of motion in the context of special relativity Einstein derived that E = mc^2 -- in other words that mass has a "rest energy."

If an electron and an anti-matter electron (known as the positron) bump into each other then their is total energy conversion. The mass of two electrons is converted into energy.

In a fission or fusion bomb the the atomic process (breaking apart a heavy atom, or fusing some light atoms) results in a  much smaller conversion of mass to energy. But still a lot compared with normal explosives.

Question: what is an opto-coupler?
Answer: In electronics, an opto-isolator (or optical isolator, optocoupler) is a device that uses a short optical transmission path to transfer a signal between elements of a circuit, typically a transmitter and a receiver, while keeping them electrically isolated — since the signal goes from an electrical signal to an optical signal back to an electrical signal, electrical contact along the path is broken.\nA common implementation involves an LED and a light sensor, separated so that light may travel across a barrier but electrical current may not.

Question: Could time travel ever be possible?
Answer: No. Einstein's theory of relativity is commonly misinterpreted by non-scientists as "proof" that time travel is possible. Question: how can u cure pain of arthritis?
Answer: If you haven't had a clinical diagnosis, don't give up on the possibility that your pain might not be arthritis. My husband had a variety of symptoms, one of which was joint and bone pain. The doctors tested him for rhumatoid, but the results came back negative. It turned out that he had celiac disease. Celiac primarily impacts the digestive system, but advanced cases of the disease get all sorts of autoimmune problems and nutrient deficiencies - one of which is bone and joint pain. Once he quit getting gluten in his diet his pain completely went away. \n\nIf he gets a gluten infraction the pain will return. We had that last summer when they had cookouts at work pretty regularly for several weeks in a row. He was careful to select foods that were gluten free, but he kept getting a reaction each time. Since he could find no initial cause, he figured he just had a mild viral infection. By the end of two weeks he had terrible bone and joint pain. We finally discovered that Kingsford charcoal uses gluten as a binding agent in their bricketts. The cookouts were with Kingsford. Kingsford stated that the gluten would burn up completely and couldn't contaminate the food; however, my husband's body showed them to be wrong. He quite eating the grilled foods and his symptoms subsided in just a few days. We have come arcross several other celiacs since then who said they had the same problem with Kingsford.\n\nSo, if your doctor hasn't difinitively gotten test results that prove arthritis, do a bit of research to see what conditions have this pain as a symptom.\n\nGood luck.

Question: How is it better than equations?\nAnd what would be a real world experience that you would use inequalities?

If you have to see how much money you can spend with out going over the allotted amount, would be a real world situation. Question: What really distinguishes AJAX programming from traditional web programming (html/javascript)?
Answer: AJAX uses a bit of javascript that uses the XmlHTTP object.  This object, opens up a connection to a Web server, transmits and receives data, then calls back the javascript on the page which was used to invoke it.\n\nWhat this means is that changes on the client side can communicate with the server, then dynamically update the client user interface without having to request a new Web page from the server.\n\nWhile this slightly complicates developing Web applications that use AJAX technologies (which, by the way, is just a name given to the various technologies employed to use this methodology), it makes for a very smooth user experience since they are not constantly refreshing Web pages.\n\nAJAX applications give an appearance of a 'thick client' application while still being a 'thin client' (i.e. application that runs in a Web browser.)  However, it is important to note that network communication is still going on in the background while the application is being used.

Question: What unwritten laws were the Nazis punished for at Nuremeberg?
Answer: The Nazis weren's punished for breaching unwritten laws. The restriction of trial and punishment by the international tribunal to personnel of the Axis countries has led to accusations of victor's justice and that Allied war crimes could not be tried. However it is usual that the armed forces of a civilised country  issue their forces with detailed guidance on what is and is not permitted under their military code. These are drafted to include any international treaty obligations and the customary laws of war. For example at the trial of Otto Skorzeny his defence was in part based on the Field Manual published by the War Department of the United States Army, on 1 October 1940, and the American Soldiers' Handbook.\n\n The unconditional surrender of the Axis powers was unusual and led directly to the formation of the international tribunals. Usually international wars end conditionally and the treatment of suspected war criminals makes up part of the peace treaty. In most cases those who are not prisoners of war are tried under their own judicial system if they are suspected of committing war crimes – as happened the end of the concurrent Continuation War and led to the war-responsibility trials in Finland. In restricting the international tribunal to trying suspected Axis war crimes, the Allies were acting within normal international law.\n\nThe legal basis for the jurisdiction of the court was that defined by the Instrument of Surrender of Germany, political authority for Germany had been transferred to the Allied Control Council which having sovereign power over Germany could choose to punish violations of international law and the laws of war. Because the court was limited to violations of the laws of war, it did not have jurisdiction over crimes that took place before the outbreak of war on September 1, 1939.

Question: What does a secretary do? and what does a treasurer do?
Answer: Is this for an organization? If yes, a secretary is basically a scribe and keeper of records of an organization. He/she makes the necessary paperworks for the higher officer's approval such as letters, proposals, etc. In an office, the task is pretty much the same in general, but an office secretary is more clerical in function which includes transcribing and writing the letters of the boss, filing, answering the fones, scheduling the boss's time, do other stuff the boss requires, etc.\n\nThe treasurer is the keeper of financial accounts. Most of the time, the treasurer holds the purse of an org. But he/she is the most likely person accountable for the wrongful disbursement of money. The treasurer should know how to monitor where the money goes so that s/he can regularly report the org's financial status. s/he should keep receipts or evidences of where the money is being used.\n\nIn some organizations, to prevent misuse of funds, bank accounts are co-signed by other officers besides the treasurer. So both signatories are the most accountable for embezzlement in unfortunate cases.\n\nP.S. In check the organization's bylaws and guidelines because some orgs have additional tasks for each positions, e.g. secretary sometimes dual-tasks as media officer, etc.

Question: I'm trying to  match it masculine/feminine and trying to congegate correctly! Help!!! Please explain your answer!
Answer: If you are describing yourself (you said you're a girl) it's desordenada.\n\nFrom your question I can see that you're still confused with the grammar rules of Spanish.  This is not conjugation, but rather creation of an adjective from a verb.  When you do this (in general) you drop the -ar, and add 'ado' if you're talking about a masculine noun and 'ada' if you're talking about a feminine noun.  That's why "desordenado" would be the adjective to describe a boy and "desordenada" would be the adjective to describe a girl.\n\n'des' is always the prefix in Spanish.  There's no 'dis'.

Title: 40 years old and am starting medical school?

Title: Why does ur body itch after u exercise for the first time in a long time?
Question: I jogged a mile yesterday for the first time in 2 years and my legs itched like they were on fire!
Answer: Actually, the sensation of itching is nothing more than energy being transferred through that area of your body. Two things were happening while you were jogging.

1.Your feet and legs were absorbing impact energy from the act of running. This is no different from hitting the palm of your hand against the table top over and over again. The atoms in your hand swell from the absorbed energy and then once you stop hitting the table, slowly release that energy in an attempt to get back to their normal existing ground state. the transferring or processing of that absorbed energy will feel like itching which is really just a lesser degree of pain.

2.Your legs were also releasing stored energy throughout your leg muscles during your run, adding to the absorbed energy from running. 

This is also why a sunburn will itch like crazy, absorbed solar energy is finding a way out of your body.

As your body cools down the itching may get worse, because cooling will close your pores, trapping the heat.

Hope this helps

Question: what causes deja vu? any scientific answers?
Answer: The next time you get deja vu, you know, at that moment you realize you've done this before - try to figure out what will happen next! You can't! But if, as most people think, you've lived the experience before, you should have no problem remembering what is to follow. Here's why you can never remember what will follow. When we experience anything, our brain records it and stores it as a memory. Then that memory is "filed" so that when we recall it, we can determine the sequence of the event, i.e. was this recent, or years ago? When the brain "misfiles' a current event as being something in the past, it recognizes that event and we feel we've experienced it before. But actually, our brain is comparing the current event to itself! That's why we can never follow through with what happens next...because it hasn't happened yet! And that, my friend is deja vu!

Question: This is a dumb question to ask but... "How do women get their periods?"?
Answer: Similar to circadian rhythms (daily rhythms), healthy women who are ovulating have another rhythm controlled by hormones-commonly known as their "period."  The cycle is about 28-days.  Interestingly enough, this about coincides with the cycle of the moon and there are animals which only mate during a full moon.  Although not proved, it is possible that somewhere in our evolutionary past, we had an ancestor who found that mating during a full moon improved its chances of survival.  Another theory is that the 28-day cycle prevents multiple pregnancies (i.e., multiple fertile eggs in the uterus) with multiple ages--something that could be harmful to the woman's and fetus's health.

Title: Planning a Christmas theme wedding?
Question: Am helping a friend plan a Christmas theme wedding for next year. What details and touches would you incorporate?\n\nThey are having the ceremony at the reception site.
Answer: We planned our wedding, in six weeks, for the week before Christmas.  We also had the ceremony at the reception site.  First, you should see if the site will already be decorating for the holidays.  Ours did and it saved us so much money.  We served Roast Beef and Chicken family style (trays were brought to the tables and people served themselves).  The guys wore silver vests and the girls wore apple red.  Our cake was white with a silver ribbon wrapped around it.  For our wedding favors I purchased 150 small silver bells with hearts on the top that also doubled as placecard holders.  We also had a friend bake us gingerbread men and woman and "dressed" them up with tuxes and dresses (using basic frosting).  The bells were perfect for those guests who are obsessed with having the bride and groom kiss every ten seconds!  I think it would be a great idea to do a christmas theme.  It always seems to put people in great spirits and we got some amazing pictures in front of the decorated christmas tree.

Question: What do you think of this televised Olypmics?
Answer: I remember back in 1984 being enthralled by the Olympics in Los Angeles. Every night for two weeks, my family was glued to the set to get the updates from the day's events.  We didn't have to watch 8- to 10-hours of coverage to see who won. All we had to do was wait until prime-time and we could see in one hour who the big winners were, and then spend another one or two hours watching a live event.\n\nNow, 20 years later, around-the-clock coverage is given on no fewer than 10 stations, not counting the foreign language presentations.  The updates my family got when I was a kid are only given briefly on the fly from one event to another.\n\nI feel overwhelmed with all of the coverage. It feels like the covering network has placed that much coverage to fit in all the big-name sponsors and to sell their shows.  Granted, if it weren't for this type of coverage, we wouldn't see some of the more unusual events, like curling, which in the past were treated as more of a side-bar of the games.  But the complete onslaught of the games is a bit much.

Title: where is the option to reformat using the winXP cd?
Question: other answers say "insert your winXP cd, and there should be an option to reformat".  there isn't, at least not on the main screen.  where is the reformat option at?
Answer: You have to boot off your CD in order to have the option to reformat.  Merely inserting the CD while running windows will not give you this menu.  \n\nMost computers have the ability to boot off cd, but some have this feature disabled.  If you leave the CD in your drive and restart your computer and you get a Press any key to boot from CD message then you're in the clear.  You won't (usually) need to press F6 to add any SCSI controllers and you'll want to do an advanced install, not an upgrade.  From that menu it should give you a screen that lists you partitions and there should be an option to delete the partitions and yes recreate them.  \n\nThis is not a trivial task even if you don't have to change your BIOS options to allow CD Booting.  This is not for the faint hearted and while you may want to know how to do this, perhaps it is better that you get someone who has done this to help you through it, like a smart neighbour kid or something.

Title: What is degenartive arthritis?
Question: What can I do for it and how I can I get it so I can ride broncos again.
Answer: Degenerative Arthritis is basically joints that are deteriorating.  Joints deteriorate for several reasons.  Previous injury(fractures, ligament tears, repetitive microtrauma), can also be from diet(eating an inflammatory diet of meats, fried foods and carbohydrates) vs. eating plenty of green vegetables and drinking plenty of water to start.  There is a ton of stuff that contribute toward degerative arthritis, the main thing is lifestyle choices that we choose through out our lives.  Lifestyle choices such as exercise, diet, sleep, mental attitude, keeping all joints healthy and mobile.  If you are interested in keeping your joints from getting worse, I would recommend going to a chiropractor.  They are the only ones who will address joint problems.  They will not give you medications which cover up the symptoms of the joint problems, but actually coach you in a way to better joint function and improve your health. Title: Please tell me that  what sort of education training and facility a mentally retarded child can get in USA and
Question: and how much expenditure will occur to parents to deal with it
Answer: It depends on which state you go to regarding the actual quality of services and available resources for when your child reaches adulthood.  My state (New Mexico) is actually very good in what it has to offer.

If your annual income is below $30,000 per year, all medical is covered (including therapies not provided by the schools...in other words...not of issue in accessing the educational environment) through Medicaid. If your income is above $30,000, your work's private insurance may not want to cover "developmental" medical and therapy.... check with your employer and the schools about funding supports.
ALL states must provide the following, per the laws "Individuals with Disabilities Education Act" (IDEA) and "No Child Left Behind Act" (NCLB).

1. Child find -- From birth, state services are offered for therapies, respite care, and family supports (it's difficult to raise a special needs kid), coordinated by a social worker. The focus is to help the family cope with the additional demands of raising a special needs child, and to prepare that child for the school setting.

2. At age 3 -- Pre-school for identified kids, provided through the public schools, brings various therapies in (speech, occupational, physical, counseling, etc.), and provides early exposure to academic and life skills training, as well as early training for successful participation in the school environment.

3. At age 5 -- Direct educational services at the neighborhood school (except in rare instances, when there is a centralized program that will better benefit the child... for example, I have students transferred from other schools to participate in my gifted education program, another teacher has students transferred in to participate in the behavioral intervention program). This is provided through the concept of "Least Restrictive Environment," in which the primary question is how much of this child's education can be provided effectively in the regular ed classroom? Students are provided with pull-out (part-day programming) or segregated (all-day programming) programs based on their educational needs. The goal is to try to have the child participate with the regular educational community as frequently as possible, with a key components being learning effectiveness and student safety. Students are also provided with various therapies (as noted above in pre-school), assistive technology if needed, and parent education and supports through the special education social worker(s) for the school.

4. at age 14 -- Transitional period. Students continue receiving the educational services above, plus the focus starts to change to how the child will live as an adult. A high-school coursework plan is put in place, and it is decided whether the child will work toward a standard diploma (just like the regular education students) or a certificate (for life skills training). Parents are linked to social services for adults as provided by the state and the local/regional community. The child now starts attending the planning sessions, and has a voice in how the committee decides his/her future.

5. Age 18 -- unless the parents have extended their custody of the child through the state (usually done for Mentally Retarded or multi-disabled students), the student now has planning control of his/her education. The parent no longer attends the meetings, unless the student directly invites them.

6. The year of the student's 22nd birthday -- if the student has not earned a standard diploma, the student "graduates" with the certificate indicating participation and learning growth in the individualized program. All services that might still be needed, are provided through state and community organizations, not the schools.

In New Mexico, the state program for severe and profound adults is called the "Developmentally Delayed Waiver." It "waives" the person's adult

Question: If passing out means killing brain cells, do getting drunk kill brain cells?
Answer: The idea that alcohol kills brain cells has long been promoted. The early temperance writers made this assertion and also insisted that the alcohol in their blood could cause “drunkards” to catch fire and burn aliveThis combustion argument against drinking was dropped long ago but many anti-alcohol writers continue to promote the idea that even moderate drinking causes brain cells to die.\nScientific medical research has actually demonstrated that the moderate consumption of alcohol is associated with better cognitive (thinking and reasoning) skills and memory than is abstaining from alcohol. Moderate drinking doesn’t kill brain cells but helps the brain function better into old ageOf course, years of alcohol abuse can cause serious neurological damage, including Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Harm can be done to message-carrying dendrites on neurons in the cerebellum, a part of the brain involved in learning and physical coordination. But even in such extreme cases, there’s a lack of evidence that alcohol kills brain cellsHowever, abstinence after chronic alcohol abuse enables brains to repair themselves, according to new research involving rats.People who drink too much and are thinking about either reducing or eliminating their drinking should find these findings encouraging, although humans have not yet been tested directly for the positive brain effects

Question: What is a kundalini or sokrlung experience. I meditated for two months and felt warm now i have mental illness
Answer: Asian traditions recognize a number of pitfalls associated with intensive meditation practice, such as altered perceptions that can be frightening, and "false enlightenment," associated with delightful or terrifying visions (Epstein, 1990). Epstein (1990) describes a "specific mental disorder that the Tibetans call 'sokrlung' (a disorder of the 'life-bearing wind that supports the mind' that can arise as a consequence...of strain[ing] too tightly in an obsessive way to achieve moment-to-moment awareness" (p. 27). When meditative practices are transplanted into Western contexts, the same problems can occur. Anxiety, dissociation, depersonalization, altered perceptions, agitation, and muscular tension have been observed in western meditation practitioners (Bogart, 1991; Walsh & Roche, 1979). Yet Walsh and Roche (1979) point out that "such changes are not necessarily pathologic and may reflect in part a heightened sensitivity" (p. 1086).

Question: what is the sixth sense of human body?
Answer: Balance is our true sixth sense - it enables us to sense how our bodies are moving around in the world and keep us upright. There are only two kinds of animal that spend their whole lives performing the tricky balancing act of walking on two legs – humans and some flightless birds, like ostriches.

Balancing can be a deceptively complex business. Nigel Marven joins stunt co-ordinator Marc Cass for a dramatic drive and experiences how the balance organs let us know how we're being yanked around and even turned upside down.

Help from the eyes 
For really fine balance, we need our eyes. They help us to work out exactly what the body is doing relative to the outside world. A troupe of acrobats at the Circus School in San Francisco illustrate this when they perform a human tower in darkness.

Nigel reveals why spinning round in circles makes you dizzy. And, under the guidance of Dr Ros Davies from the National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery, he discovers why drinking alcohol makes it hard to walk in a straight line and can make your head spin.

Our sense of balance is so complex that even if all components are working fine – the balance organs, the feedback from our limbs, and our eyes – if there there's any disagreement about what's going on, the result can be unpleasant. Dr Frank Golden of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution explains that sea sickness is caused when the central nervous system receives conflicting messages from these three systems.

Question: wht is kinesics?
Answer: Kinesics is the science of body language. Nonverbal gestures, postures and facial expressions by which a person manifests various physical, mental or emotional states, and communicates nonverbally with others.

These messages delivered through nonverbal cues, which can be either verbal or physical, can support, emphasize or contradict what is being conveyed.

In face-to-face selling, Kinesics are often used to emphasize key benefits. But they are particularly important because they can drive important points home -- such as by adding emotion to a sales pitch, which go beyond words.

Uncrossing of the arms or legs. Raising of the brows. Rubbing of the chin. Leaning forward. All of these can indicate that you're interested in your client -- or if the client does it, it can tell you she's interested in your offer.

Question: Which direction does a twister twist in, clockwise or counter-clockwise? does hemisphere change that?
Answer: In the Northern Hemisphere, a tornado or twister twists counter-clockwise. In the Southern Hemisphere is clockwise. This is due to the Coriolis effect, caused when objects (in this case air) moves over the rotating earth. The air flows towards the twister, but curves to right (relative to the direction it is flowing). It is easier to visualize if you think about some air flowing straight north to a twister. Since the earth's surface is moving faster towards the east where it started, it carry on some of the momentum and curve to the east (right of the northerly direction it was flowing). This will tend to cause the air to miss the twister, but he extreme low pressure will allow the higher pressure around it to bend the flow towards the funnel, but the air will have the angular momentum of moving the right as it moves in, thus creating the counter-clockwise twist. In the Southern Hemisphere, a flow from the south towards a twister will be coming from a place closer to the earth's axis, and thus will be moving East more slowly than the land under the twister, so it fall behind (to the West) as it approaches, resulting, through the similar process as described above, in a clockwise twist.

Answer:

Title: Why would a defendant use a Brady motion?
Question: I know someone who is guilty of a crime and should be punished, but his lawyer requested a Brady at trial - what does that mean to the case?
Answer: Dear Friend,\n\nA Brady motion generally means that the defendant believes the police or prosecutor has withheld evidence which would tend to show his innocence. var_dump($_GET);

Title: Which one you choose:A frozen marriage,with confused children or  a divorce .?
Question: Some people think that divorce is nothing big ,some people think  that no matter how unhappy the marriage is,we should keep it for the kids.What do you think?
Answer: Quite the conundrum.

There are such things as survivable marriages.  Divorce really should be a last, last, last resort, especially once kids are involved.

That said, there can be a point where more harm comes to the kids with a bitter marriage.  Mom and Dad never get along.  One or both drink too much, are never home, abusive, etc.  

Kids are fairly resilient.  They recover well so long as both parents remember that through divorce the kids needs are most important.  

I'm in a good (not great) marriage.  I could easily get "lazy" and neglect my marriage based on this.  (Cheating, withdrawing etc) but the kids need a stable family and my life really isn't all that bad.  (After all, I CHOSE my wife and CHOSE to have kids).  

Divorce is NEVER good when kids are involved.  It is a question of which is the worse of two evils:  A less than good marriage with the family working to hold together or a impulsive divorce that destroys kids faith in adults, parents and family.

- They de-emphasize the church...therefore leaving less influenece, power, and control over the religion for the church

- They did not properly imply the possibility that Jesus was God.

Question: how do you know if u have a mic on yur puter so people in voice chat can hear. it worked one day, now it doesn
Answer: Maybe it's muted, or maybe it's not selected for recording!

[Assuming you have Windows]
Open Volume Control by double clicking the Speaker icon in the system tray (notification area). (also, Start > [All] Programs > Accessories > Multimedia/Entertainment > Volume Control)

On the menubar, select Options > Properties.

In the Properties dialog, select "Recording" under "Adjust volume for", and click OK

Now you should see "Recording Control". Place a tick mark in the check box called "Select" that directly appears below "Microphone". Adjust your mic volume. Too low, nobody can hear anything. Too high, it will squeak!

If your mic is not performing well even at highest, lower it to the lowest, then go to Options > Advanced Controls. Place a tick mark on the check box named "Mic Boost", "Mic Gain" or something similar. Click OK, and adjust the volume again. (If you don't find Mic Boost, your hardware doesn't support this feature)

Note: It is recommended that you leave the microphone muted in Volume Control, while it is selected for recording in the Recording Control. This ensures that your voice will not be echoed in your speakers.

To share music that is playing on your computer, select the "Line-In", "CD" or something related directly to the source of the music, instead of the microphone as the recording device.

Viva La Dvorak! - www.dvzine.org

Title: Why do humans have the majority of hair constantly grow on head/face?
Question: Think about it! What other mammal has this characteristic?
Answer: In contrast to most mammals, humans do not have an all-embracing intense hair on their body. Several theories have been advanced to explain the bareness of human body hair. One suggests that nature selected humans for shorter and thinner body hair as part of a set of adaptations including bipedal locomotion and an upright posture. There are several problems with this savanna theory, not least of which is that cursorial hunting is used by (other) animals that do not show any thinning of hair, and that hair similar to chimpanzees and gorillas also shades the skin from radiant heat and protects it from hot winds, and thus another mechanism for heat loss is not required. Another problem is that bipedal locomotion apparently now predates hominids moving from a forest environment to a savanna environment. A more recent theory for human hair loss has to do with a possible period of bipedal wading in a salt marsh in the Danakil region of Ethiopia, possibly occurring in the hominid lineage between 5 and 7 million years ago. As a wading animal, it was more efficient to develop short body hair and a layer of subcutaneous fat for streamlining and insulation in the aquatic environment; the eccrine sweat glands developed later after the hominids left the water; see Aquatic ape hypothesis. One problem with this theory is that both chimpanzees and gorillas have the same density and distribution of the eccrine glands, but that they have not been developed for sweat production.\n\nA third theory for the thin body hair on humans proposes that Fisherian runaway sexual selection played a role here (as well as in the selection of long head hair). Possibly this occurred in conjunction with neoteny, with the more juvenile appearing females being selected by males as more desirable; see types of hair and vellus hair. The human female body hair typically has more vellus hair (making the skin appear bare), while the male body typically has more terminal hair (especially on the chest, abdomen and back). Thus sexual selection can explain the sexual dimorphism in human body hair, with the results of selection being more evident (more extreme) in the female than in the male, a point which the other two theories cannot address without proposing substantially different behavior between males and females. Also, we see that artificially bare (shaved, etc.) legs, arms, etc. on women are seen as "sexy" even today, while body shaving is not nearly as common for men.

Answer: The Knicks has been a bad team mainly because of poor judgement and the pressure to win. Management are making poor decisions on what to do with this team (pulling the trigger on uncecessary trades, bad free agent signing) that results to forcing to trade players with big contracts anaually, but everytime they do that, they inherit another big contract that doesn't pan out. There are some patterns like dips that may be more stressful, but you can avoid them, since you're leading. Question: the police reports that the total braking distance by the car was 71 ft.

Answer: Assuming that this drag factor gives the maximum fraction of g that the car could decelerate at then using a=32*.75 gives a=24ft/s/s and the initial velocity would have been roughly sqrt(2*24*71) ft/s (say 58.5ft/s)
5280ft in a mile and 3600 seconds in an hour means mph=ft/s*3600/5280 , about 40mph.
At 25mph ~ about 36.6ft/s the same decelleration would have stopped the car in 36.6^2/2/24 feet so yes the pedestrian would have been fine. all the above used v^2=u^2+2as
with a=acceleration in ft/s/s (-ve as acting in the opposite direction to u), s in feet, v=final velocity = 0 and u=initial velocity in ft/s.

Question: how are linux red hat and windows xp different.?
Answer: Linux is an open source software. What that means is that code that is written to make the final software is freely available for modification and reuse - given that you release your modifications to the public.

Windows is a line of products released by Microsoft. Unlike Linux, MS does not release the code of there operating system (OS). Windows XP is the latest version of there OS.

Linux in its bare-bone format is not easily usable. To be able to use it you need some software that run on it and some drivers to identify your hardware. Normally Linux comes with a lot of software that is developed by under the GNU project by volunteers for the Free Software Foundation. Under this form Linux is called GNU/Linux.

Since Linux can be modified a lot of vendors have released their own version of Linux one of those vendors is RedHat. They release Fedora Linux for the public and RedHat Linux for corporate use. It differs from bare bone Linux in that it comes with an installer and several useful utilities and programs developed either under GNU or by Red hat or by other companies mostly under the same license - GPL.

So primarily the difference is that Linux can be modified but Windows can not. But there are several other finer differences. For most people Linux is about choice. Anyway you can read the details here http://www.michaelhorowitz.com/Linux.vs.Windows.html

Title: Modern Human Evolution?  How did all populations of humans advance at the same time?
Question: For approximately 150-200,000 years, humans essentially lived like very smart animals, then fairly suddenly, about 10,000 years ago, we all seemed to have discovered agriculture and "civilization"..a few thousand years later we were all writing.  I have never seen a decent, logical explanation for how all the populations of the Earth took this "great leap forward" at the same time-After 150-200,000 years, suddenly within about 1% of that time frame, there are cities everywhere from the Middle East, to China, to North and South America?  Writing starting independently everywhere?  For me, this is the most mysterious event in all of history-any ideas?
Answer: Hey! Your "other" question is already cluttered up with some high voltage discussion and nice arguements so, I thought I should post my answer here as it is more peaceful and calm here. I was wondering whether I should have posted my answer there? 

Now, I'll try to make sense while talking about a topic that I know little about. 

1- It all started with the arrival of the first bipedal- Australopithecus anamensis. (some might argue that it was Ardipithecus ramidus). Ok, the point is, as our ancestors started to learn to walk on two feet, they had some challenges to face as bipedalism reduced their speed considerably putting them at a clear disadvantage against their predators.
Now, as this problem was faced by all the hominids all over the world at the same time, it led to some parallel thoughts (and thus inventions and discoveries) all over the world e.g. building homes, making weapons and tools etc. (The stone tools were first made by the handy man i.e. Homo habilis and not Australopithecus).
This tool technology was spread by Homo ergaster as they  migrated outside Africa.

2- Then, in the course of evolution, the early humans started to have a complex cultural lives and they grew emotionally, e.g. the Neanderthals (who aren't our direct ancestors) started to bury the dead.

3- As the homo species like homo erectus, homo neanderthalis, homo heidelbergenesis and ancient homo sapiens (Cro Magnon) made further advances in creativity and productivity, they all felt a natural need to pen down their thoughts. This led to the cave painitngs and carvings. All of those paintings can be interpreted as diary entries as you may see that the paintings and carvings simply depict what the early men "did" i.e. hunting, using tools etc.
So, I guess it is understandable why the "pictorial-scripts" developed contemporarily to each other.

4- But the question still remains: Why were the origin of world's ancient scripts so contemporary to each other? I guess, as man found the pictorial depiction of thoughts and emotions more and more unconvenient and tedious due to the diverseness of thoughts and situations to be depicted, it started taking help of symbols. Perhaps, this behaviour was so "human-like" that every sub-species of the homo sapiens followed this pattern of 'depicting thoughts symbolically' universally.

5- Another reason of this might be migration. Before the ancient civilizations like Inka, Mesopotamia, Egyptian etc. even came into existence, the early hominids led a nomadic life. According to the "Out of Africa Hypothesis", all the modern humans "Homo Sapiens" originated from Africa. Later, they migrated to Africa, Asia and Europe and formed groups.
So, I guess due to their similar ancestral origins, the human beings had a common problem solving approach and hence, attempted the problem of inconvenience of pictorial scripts in a nearly identical manner.

The scientific difference in the scripts can explain that they were devised on completely different grounds but, the approach was similar due to common origins and creative grounds.

Question: how long should a white dental filling last?

If I can not get a good (dry) environment for placing a white filling, I sigh a little bit and go ahead and use a silver filling.\n\nAs far as asking how long tooth-colored fillings last, let me say this. Many of those fillings are still there, because I was very cautious about where I did them.  I'd say I was really on the bandwagon by about 1985-1990 and practically every while filling I've done (to my knowledge) is still serving. Question: Why once fruiting, a Banana tree do not produce fruits again?
Answer: The banana "tree" is not a tree at all but a shoot from an underground stem. When it flowers, the growing tip of the shoot becomes a flowering stem when then supports the fruits. Since the growing part of the shoot can no longer grow (because it was converted into a flowering shoot) the whole shoot dies off after the fruit has been set. The plant itself is mostly underground; it doesn't die but produces more shoots (more "trees").

Title: Does Fractals and Chaos Theories directly apply to Thermodynamics Laws?
Question: Lawws of thermodynamics
Answer: Well, this was one aspect of my research thesis in Physics of about 10 years ago. The big picture is quite wide, so let's focus on a particular property of classical thermodynamics that is challenged by the chaotic behavior of certain systems: the equipartition of energy.
Classical thermodynamics tells us that, providing enough time, a system goes to equipartition, i.e. its energy is apportioned in equal parts along all the degrees of freedom. It is well known that the equipartition law has been disproved by quantum mechanics, but until some years ago it was believed a necessary consequence of classical mechanics.
The news is that the recent studies (including my little contribution) have shown that there are certain systems for which, under given conditions, neither classical mechanics prescribe the equipartition of energy.
A class of such systems is constituted by the nonlinear Hamiltonian lattices, that is, N-dimensional spring/mass chains with nonlinear springs. To make it simple, consider that some solid gasses have their atoms stuffed in crystals that can be modeled as such lattices.
These systems are classified as chaotic (or also stochastic) for mathematical reasons too complex to be explained here.
Suppose you freeze Helium at the point that it solidifies. Then you have such a crystal. Its degrees of freedom are the harmonic modes of oscillation of the crystal (just like the harmonic sounds in a guitar string). From the equipartition law one should expect that, after waiting some time, all harmonics go to the same energy. But this is not the case: most energy remains instead concentrated in the lower harmonics. The effect is stronger as the temperature decreases.
Obviously these results are mainly obtained thanks to computer simulations, because the involved equations have no analytic solution.
Surprisingly, some of these results match with the prediction of quantum mechanics. This is clearly a debated issue but it suggests anyway that the "old-fashioned" classical mechanics has still something to say in modern physics!

Later addition (in relation to the "Additional Details" above): yes, of course I'm speaking of deterministic chaos here, in the mathematical sense (thought it was obvious).

Answer:

Question: 16 year old high school junior plays point guard at Lemoore High School.  Lemoore, California.  Lemoore has highest ratio of made 3 point shots in central section, Alex has highest ratio at Lemoore High School.  5'9" 160lbs.  3.5gpa
Answer: Believe it or not, the coaches usually come to you -- early.  I know a 15-year-old, 6'3" high school basketball star who started receiving letters from universities as a freshman.  This was before he was invited to join the varsity basketball team as a freshman.  In short, Big Ten university coaches have been courting him and his parents since he was 14.

Since your star has not been approached at this point, you must take matter into your own hands.  Despite the height factor, treat your star like a product.  Become your own Arliss or Jerry Maguire, i.e., sports agent.  Look at the college sports pages for top twenty lists to map out your target schools.  Assemble a media kit with the newspaper clippings, high school transcripts, a personal essay, letters of recommendation from faculty and community leaders, and action photographs of your star.  Pitch your star to the head coach and assistant coaches.  If they require more information, offer to send them a media kit.  Request an interview.  If possible try to bring your star to meet the coach if his/her team is playing at a nearby university.  Send a thank you note.

If that does not work, network, network, network ... Cultivate relationships with the sports writers at your local and big city newspapers and the sports anchors of your local television networks.  Ask for help.  Then ask for recommendations.  For the most part, if your star is not on the front page of the sports section, then you must be aggressive in gaining coverage.  

Additional keys to boosting the profile of your star are park districts, regional tournaments, traveling teams, basketball festivals, and summer camps.  The more people know about the talents of your star, the better.  It may sound overwhelming (and expensive), but practice and multiple performance venues make perfect public relations for budding NCAA stars.  If your star has not been playing basketball year-round, since kintergarten, then expedite your media campaign -- yesterday.

If your star is really a star, then a scholarship is in your reach.  So, roll up your sleeves and claim it.  Ask the basketball coach, athletic director, principal and teachers for support in your endeavor because the universities will confirm your information.

Question: How do you control your nerves?
Answer: Learn to manage your stress and your nerves will take care of themselves...
stress relief pointers
think really seriously about and talk with others, to identify the causes of the stress and take steps to remove, reduce them or remove yourself (the stressed person) from the situation that causes the stress. 
Understand the type(s) of stressors affecting you (or the stressed person), and the contributors to the stress susceptibility - knowing what you're dealing with is essential to developing the stress management approach. 
improve diet - group B vitamins and magnesium are important, but potentially so are all the other vitamins and minerals: a balanced healthy diet is essential. Assess the current diet and identify where improvements should be made and commit to those improvements. 
reduce toxin intake - obviously tobacco, alcohol especially - they might seem to provide temporary relief but they are working against the balance of the body and contributing to stress susceptibility, and therefore increasing stress itself. 
take more exercise - generally, and at times when feeling very stressed - exercise burns up adrenaline and produces helpful chemicals and positive feelings. 
stressed people must try to be detached, step back, look from the outside at the issues that cause the stress. 
don't try to control things that are uncontrollable - instead adjust response, adapt. 
share worries - talk to someone else - off-load, loneliness is a big ally of stress, so sharing the burden is essential. 
increase self-awareness of personal moods and feelings - anticipate and take steps to avoid stress build-up before it becomes more serious. 
explore and use relaxation methods - they do work if given a chance - yoga, meditation, self-hypnosis, massage, a breath of fresh air, anything that works and can be done in the particular situation.

Question: when was flatland bmxing started?
Answer: I ride flatland and own a flatland bike shop. Here's some info.

Flatland is a BMX riding style that is performed on smooth flat surfaces, often with flatland specific frames, front & rear bolt on axle pegs, a hollow stem bolt for the front brake cable, and rear brake detangler or "gyro" to facilitate the bars being able to rotate endlessy without tangling the brake cables. Also invented specifically for flatland bmx riding was the rear hub mechanism called a "freecoaster", that allows the rear wheel to roll backwards without engaging the hub to make the pedals rotate around. Other technical bicycle setup specifics can include narrow handlebars, rear hand brakes and a Gyro rear brake cable detangler device, very high pressure tires, and a very small front sprocket. But in concept, any BMX bike with axle pegs could be used for flatland riding.

In a contest, your talent and skill is judged by your ability to maintain coordination and balance while performing a variety of difficult and elegant moves. There are usually several categories for judging purposes which can include:

number of touches, i.e. = the number of times a rider does not complete their trick and/or touches their foot to the ground 
number of tricks completed in the alloted time 
difficulty of the tricks; which can be very subjective, as flatland bmx has become as (if not, more) technical in many ways as figure skating and breakdancing 
originality of the tricks performed; which again is fairly subjective 
style and flow; which means how smooth and/or stylish did the rider perform their moves during the contest run. 
Flatland is an involving, time-consuming discipline where the rider learns different balance, counter-balance points and center-of-gravity in motion through repetition and trial-and-error. Some tricks can be learned in hours, others may take years to achieve.

Some flatland riders would refer to flatland as a type of art, and would place the emphasis on being original, while others consider having the most or hardest tricks the important thing, and still others ride just for fun. There is no right or wrong, and only contest riders need to be concerned with the competitive side of things, as there are many riders who prefer doing shows, having parts in videos, or simply riding with their friends and enjoying themselves as much as winning a contest.

Riders usually pedal a few times for speed, and perform various stunts often involving difficult and/or awkward stances on pegs, mounted to the axle of their front or back wheels. Pegs are hollow metal tubes, which are bolted onto both sides of the front and back axles. When flatland riding first came into being, most riders would do one trick, and then get back to the pedals and that was it, but by combining different body, and bicycle positions, into "combos" and "linking" them together, riders challenge themselves further by doing several tricks in a row without stopping inbetween each move. Flatland riding is usually a combination of many different kinds of moves, often linked together in a non-stop fashion as the rider goes through as few as 2 or 3, or as many as 10-12 moves, and position or direction changes in a row, and then finally returning their feet to the pedals. It has been somewhat unelegantly compared to both ice skating, and breakdancing, and really, it is its own thing, but those comparisons will give you a vague idea of what to expect to see.

Notable flatland BMX legends include Bob Haro,Kevin Jones, Chase Gouin, Ross Smith, Bill Neumann, Pete Brandt, Jesse Puente, Chad Degroot, Andrew Faris and Trevor Meyer. Modern flatland legends that have influenced other riders include Simon O'Brien, Martti Kuoppa, Mat Wilhelm, Phil Dolan, Lee Musselwhite, Jeff Desroche, Cory Fester, Percy Marshall, Stephan Cerra, Terry Adams, and Tanaka Kotaro.

Title: why is the term nigga considered offensive by some of the black people in america?
Question: i'm a black non-american person and i also want to know the origins of this N word
Answer: The word Negro stems from the Spanish word Negro, meaning black. In English, negro or neger became negar and finally nigger, most likely under influence of French nègre. Neger (sometimes spelled "neggar") prevailed in northern New York under the Dutch and also in Philadelphia, in its Moravian and Pennsylvania Dutch communities. For example, the New York City African Burial Ground was originally known as "Begraaf Plaats van de Neger.\n\n"Nigger is an extremely derogatory term used for black people. During the period when slavery was practiced worldwide, and in particular by the United States and European countries, and for several decades after Europe and North America prohibited slavery, it was a standard, casual English term for black people. The word traditionally has been associated with an often casual contempt, a racist assumption of black inherent inferiority, even of bestiality, making it extremely pejorative. In the last 100 years it has also become a friendly and jocular term, used self referentially, among some black people.

Title: What is the difference between the following below? (Please answer and read the question below)?
Question: WHat is the difference between light dispersion, light refraction, light diffraction, and light reflection? What is another property besides diffraction, dispersion, refraction, and reflection? Please give a scientific answer.
Answer: All these produce a change in path of incident ray of light but reasons and effects are different in each:

Diffraction -- bending of light round the edges and corners, while passing through slits/holes/wires in the same medium. produces a pattern of alternate bands/fringes ( minimum/maximum intensity). they are maximum intense at the center of the path and fades of - on both the sides
shape of bands/fringes depends on the shape of obstacle(hole/slit/wire/edge)

Refraction -  bending of light , when it passes from one medium to another of a different refractive index, no pattern produced. no change in the intensity if the second medium does not reflect/absorb part of incident light.

Reflection: Change of path of light ray due to reflection, i.e the reflected ray is in the same medium as the second medium simply does neither absorbs nor allows it to pass through it. No change in the intensity and no pattern produced.

dispersion -  splitting of incident lightray into its constituent wavelengths, when it passes through a medium (like prism). every wavelength gets deviated from incident path through a different angle (angle of dispersion), hence you can see different colors of visible light.

Title: what is a firewall and what is  a trojan?
Question: please tell me about computer viruses and prevention stratagies.
Answer: (m)\n\nA firewall is a piece of hardware and/or software which functions in a networked environment to prevent some communications forbidden by the security policy, analogous to the function of firewalls in building construction. \n\nTrojan: Small malicious programs that are delivered secretly or benignly to your computer as executable files (usually through email, chat lines, FTP, Freeware or Shareware programs, MP3s or even movies)-just like the Trojan Horse, innocent looking on the outside, but containing a nasty surprise hidden inside. It is really two programs-one on your computer ("server") and the other on the cracker's ("client"). This server runs automatically every time the computer is started. A Trojan program gives the cracker complete access to your computer. There are thousands of different Trojan programs.  Trojans need user intervention to install (the file needs to be opened) and do not self-replicate like viruses.

Question: Why is the sky blue and grass green?
Answer: 1. Why the sky is blue.\nWhen light passes through a medium with molecules much smaller than the wavelength, it is scattered. You can understand it so: the light begins by going as a beam "forward". It gets absorbed for a moment by a molecule and then emitted again in whatever direction. This effect is more effective when the wavelength is shorter. Blue light has a wavelength ~2 times shorter than red light and gets scattered 16 times as effectively. So the beam coming directly from the sun is deprived of blue =>thus it is yellow (or red if it is sunset and it has passed a thick layer of atmosphere (geometry)). From all other directions we see the light that was going towards other points on the Earth. The yellows and reds went on and the blue was sent in other directions, including towards us.\n\n2. Why the grass is green.\nGreen plants use light to make food. The light is absorbed by chlorophyll (two types of it, too and a bit different, but no matter). Chlorophyll absorbs violet, blue, orange and red light. What we see is what was not absorbed, but reflected. If you take the aforementioned colours out of the white light spectrum, you get a mixtureof green and yellow. And green is the colour our eyes see best. Thus - green grass.\n\nI hope I've been clear

Answer:

To be printed on stickers-labels
Answer: Are you printing the invitations or the labels?

If you're printing the labels, you can buy those pre-cut labels in stationery shops. The sheets are usually in letter or A4 size, and you have a choice of the size of the label and thus the number of labels that fit in a sheet. 

Some label manufacturers have a template (like a sample page with the lines matching the label sheet) that you can download from their website (look up the product code). The other option is to get a label sheet that is A4 or letter size, meaning there are no smaller stickers cut into it. Then you just print normally and then cut it up with a pair of scissors.

Question: How can I make sure that my home wireless network is sure?
Answer: Log into your firewall/router using the IP address and enable WEP encryption, and change the administrator user name and password.  If you haven't done so, you can find the default IP address assigned to it in the manual. something like 198.0.0.1, then plug that IP in  the address bar in your browser and you will be prompted to enter the user name and password. which is by default usually user: admin password: administrator or vice versa. You can also check what your firewall IP is by going to the start menu, selecting run, and typing cmd then press enter. a dos window opens and you type ipconfig, then press enter, some info is returned the gateway IP is your firewall/router IP address. Once logged through the browser go to the advanced or security tab and make the necessary adjustments. for more step by step instructions I suggest visiting the manufacuter web site, consulting the manual, or googling something like "setting up secure wireless network Linksys (or whatever)"

Question: What Is Correlation and Cross Correlation?
Answer: Correlation is determining the relationship of one variable to the values of other variables using collected data.\n\nFor example if you considered a person's salary, you might find it correlates with: number of years of education, and number of years of employment, along with other variables.\n\nCross-correlation means a correlation just between 2 variables. You get that expression, because you can evaluate if two variables cross correlate, by plotting one variable on the X and one on the Y axis of a graph. If the cloud of points that result are clustered around a straight line then they cross correlate well.
